number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Hola, Amigos! It is I, your humble servant, Presidente, here to tell you about the glorious life that awaits you in Tropico... the Fourth!I love this game. Love it. Can't even begin to express how much love I have for it. Ask me what my most anticipated game at present is, and it's not the next big AAA experience, nor some indie puzzle darling, heck, part of me might even tell you it's not the games I'm trying to make. My most anticipated video game at present is Tropico 5, and that's entirely due to the strength of its predecessor. This game's steady stream of DLC, which recently ended, always got me amazingly excited, and I always tried to buy them whenever I could. As City builders go, it's accessible in all the right ways. Simple, but not dumb.First off, it's one of the most chill games I've ever played, not in its attitude, but in mine, while I play it. With Tropico 4, I like to sit back, relax, smile, and play. The game's script and attitude makes me chuckle--it's a humorous game, and one of the funniest titles to have been released in 2011 (has it really been that long?). There are tons of buildings that all work well together, and the new DLC buildings almost all feel as integral to the gameplay as the stuff that came before.Modern Times, the game's large expansion, was superb, sporting a large campaign that, among other things, involved building a ton of shanties to create a mirror to reflect a giant space laser.One thing that really makes Tropico 4 great, though, is the way choice and consequence works. Decisions you make early on in the game can prove to have incredibly positive benefits by the game's end. Or, of course, they can hurt you and drag things out. But... it's hard to lose, and that's a good thing. It's not that it's easy to win, it's just simply hard to completely fail the game. I can't even begin to tell you how many times I've hit a negative balance in my account, only to come out swinging with $50,000 and $60,000 balances quickly stacking up after. Winning is fun, and losing's so rare, it's hard to feel bad about.The game is fun, but hey, you don't have to take my word for it, because there's a demo. Go pick it up. Kick back, relax, and give it a go. Have fun. And then realize that Tropico 4's going to give you a ton more of that, but with even more varied and diverse stuff.Tropico is yours for the making.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2013
												Imagine Sim City, but set in a fictional Carribean island during the cold war. Now add eight bickering political factions and five high-and-mighty international powers, each with their own surprisingly intelligent and hilarious writing, and a 20-mission campaign that's proving to be incredibly addictive. While the first few years on your island tend to become repetitive as you log more and more hours, each island presents its own challenges, and the leaders you select (or create) always add their own twist to the mission. Finally, in a major departure from most civ-building games, the end goal isn't to build up a military; instead, your army is but one of the many things you need to take care of, and in certain cases can be completely ignored. Very happy to have paid extra to get this in the Humble Bundle, and will almost definitely get 5 when it comes out.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												City building and management simulator with a (tongue-in-cheek) twist - you play as dictator of a banana republic, some imaginary Carribean island nation of Tropico. This doesn't automatically make you a malevolent ruler, although the option is very much on the table. But you can be quite a benevolent leader, too, to avoid social unrest and having to create a police/martial law controlled state.Usually though, you'll play as a mix of both tyrant and quite legitimately democratically elected el presidente, swaying in one way or the other depending on how much actual support you currently have from your population (and there's a whole bunch of factions to appease, with often contradictory goals and beliefs, but you're going to focus on the most numerous ones, with most voters, won't you - politics, yo).While thematically quite distinct and lighthearted (dousing in cheerful latino music accentuates this), and generally comedic - the game is very much competent at what it does, simulating the needs and wants of your population down to individual people, quite organically punishing you for wrong choices by collapsing your economy and/or throwing you into a bloody civil war.Campaign makes you go island hopping, trying to build up individual islands of your nation, playing to their individual strenghts, so Tropico is the best nation ever in the entire world... but things of course inevitably but suddenly go south to comedic effects. Campaign missions have their unique predetermined goals and events, however otherwise play mostly like a sandbox game, and there's of course actual sandbox mode as well to keep you rolling.By now, at least gameplay wise, you'd maybe rather look at Tropico 5 which mixes things a bit more with multiple eras/stages of development, but this doesn't suddenly make Tropico 4 any worse or its campaign(s) no longer distinct.As for DLC business - there's plenty here in Tropico 4, and you definitely do want Modern Times which is a big expansion with its own campaign and new versions of many buildings. Other DLCs however aren't as crucial, but surely can provide some nice buildings like plantations* for more efficient agriculture or cement factory for quicker construction and resource-free export commodity, and there's always some new trait on your leader to select (this tweaks gameplay in some fashion, like more love from some faction or more efficiency in some area) and some specific mission to reinvigorate your desire to develop one more island rather than going pure sandbox again trying your own goals. It's just that for what they provide, they kind of seem individually quite pricey. (*sometimes new stuff may imbalance original campaign missions a bit, like I believe there was a mission with an island which was supposed to be agriculturally challenged and even disabled farms for you.. but didn't disable plantations (oversight?) so you could still start growing plants if you desired - not like your people would die of hunger otherwise unless you imported lots of food - you still could've had cattle ranches, it's just the mission was supposed to make you focus solely on industry rather than agriculture or tourism).

Now add eight bickering political factions and five high-and-mighty international powers, each with their own surprisingly intelligent and hilarious writing, and a 20-mission campaign that's proving to be incredibly addictive. While the first few years on your island tend to become repetitive as you log more and more hours, each island presents its own challenges, and the leaders you select (or create) always add their own twist to the mission. Finally, in a major departure from most civ-building games, the end goal isn't to build up a military; instead, your army is but one of the many things you need to take care of, and in certain cases can be completely ignored. content:
Posted: April 15, 2013
												There's an easy way to recommend this game: did you like Tropico 3? If yes, you'll dig this, if not, pass. This game's called Tropico 4 but it's nominally an expansion pack to Tropico 3, though a large one at that. Tropico is a nation-building game in the vein of the Anno series, though not nearly as in-depth and with a sense of humor. It features a few new buildings and edicts and some new mechanics, as well as an entirely new campaign. A few of the added structures make things a little easier- like the salt mine, a mine that never runs out, and the chemical plant, a factory that requires no input. The mechanic improvements serve to streamline the gameplay and the added buildings are interesting. The campaign is quite good and about 40 hours long, a decent amount of play can be had. There is of course a sandbox mode if all you wish to build is an island. I very much recommend this game if you enjoy city or nation building games.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Even though I may not have the hours on steam with this game, i've played it on my Xbox 360. It is overall a great city making game, although the graphics may be a tad outdated, it is still worth the money.Stuff you can do in game, build a city, make a economy, declare war with either or all USSR, US, China, and a few others.Setting up your own democracy and the way you would like your island life to work. There are many forms of stuff in which you can do, you can try and be self suficent or aqquire help from other factions, for army help, food, resources and espcieally financal aid. You should do the tutorial to familarize yourself with some basic skills you will need to survive and strive as El Presidente.Pros+ Runs very smooth+ Cheap for a game of this type and quality+ Is extremly fun once you get set upCons- Graphics are a bit outdated- Windows 10 removes some important textures (Generation problems)- Takes awhile to establlish a system of economyHope this review helped my personal review 8/10Buy it!Rate up :D

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												I played the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this game (a DRM-Free version), over 200 hours, completed the normal game (no DLC's) and most challenges, and well...After seeing the messed up sale of Steam the other day, that had Tropico 4 with all DLC's at 99% instead of the 85% it was supposed to have (Instead of cost like 4€'s, it costed 0,27€'s), I decided to pick it up, mainly for the DLC's.Now, I sure had fun with this game. I f#cking love "Sim City-like games", and Tropico is no different. Instead of being the God and Savior of a big♥♥♥♥♥city, you're the main ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of a little island. Yeah, that's it, you're the government, and just as in reality, government is corrupted, and filled with egomaniacs and a bunch of fat motherf#ckers. So that's a positive point to the game, it does feel right, it does make you feel like you're the Evil Morgan Freeman, and you're about to ruin arround half a thousand people's lifes.The game, sadly, has a few flaws. I haven't fully tested the DLC's yet, but it seems that some of them where just cosmetic items for the Presidente. Now that's lazy. Another big problem that I have found, is how inferior the Steam version looks, compared to the DRM-Free version: That one went smoother, with much less loading times and♥♥♥♥♥♥ I also had trouble making a new Kalipso account, but that's not the game's fault, the Outlook/Hotmail servers like to annoy their users, for some reason.Another problem I have with the game, is the soundtrack. Now, hear me on this one: It's quite great. It fits perfectly! So, what's wrong with it? It's repetitive as hell. After playing over 30 games that can easily take over 20-40 minutes, the soundtrack turns into a real pain, specially if you never liked that kind of music to begin with.The gameplay, though, it's great. Balanced and fun. My only issue, is that I don't usually get to see Rebel attacks and violent stuff. Not sure if I was too good at the game, or it's too darn easy. I do find Dark Souls an easy game (just with some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t-forced Multiplayer, the ♥♥♥♥♥iest Games for Windows servers I've seen, and a few of GOOD bosses here and there), so it's problaby I'm just crazy and nuts.I still think this game can be easily recommended to Strategy players, but be aware, this kind of games have NOTHING TO DO with other strategy games like Age of Empires. You do NOT fight other players, you fight the system. Or in this case, you're the system, and you beat up anything on your way.For this Sale's price, I think it's a darn fine deal. If the sale finishes, you should probably wait for another one, or go look for a DRM-Free version of it, there are plenty over there, even in retail versions, I believe.But now, if the game would stop to tell me that Tropico 5 has been released...WHY WOULD I CARE ABOUT TROPICO 5, IF I'M ON THE 4 ONE!? LET ME FINISH THIS ONE FIRST, DON'T YOU THINK!?

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												Absolutely fantastic game, love it - it's similar gameplay to games like sim city but without all the annoying glitchy water pipe system, you also have to deal with relationships with foreign countries and factions within your own community e.g. religious, enviromentalists, capitalists etc and try to keep everyone happy, or not... :PYou also have to educate the people within your community to satisfy the jobs you make available whether it be industrial (factories), farming, teaching, doctors,ministers etc or you can always base your income around tourism.There are many ways of making money on your island, through natural resources such as metals,lumber,fish etc. However, if you lack natural resources on your island you can always import cheap natural resources and make them into more expensive good in your factories such as jewellery and furniture and export them at a greater price. Aswell as the option of developing your island as a 'tourist trap'. I really enjoy it and would recommend it, I play it for hours straight very happily, lots of fun :D

												tyranny , dictatorship , oppression has never looked fun than in this game.basically you're a military coup leader , takeing over a piece of land , with population , doing what dictators do , aside from excuting who oppose you , you can also develop and build your very own empire. Viva la révolution.1) textures and layouts of buildings , people , life forms are on the verge between primitive or modern , in otherwords "fine"2) missions are quite fun , theres mostly just one main goal , with secondary goals and objects achieved in the way to it.3) well if you like city builder simulator , you may like this game , because its not like city builder simulator , but it actually adds some spice on it , its more than just a plain city builder sim , with no other action or content than ....building?4) if you're not familiar with tropico or haven't play any previous tropico games before , its fine , they're not related to eachother , infact , its a fine upgrade with more choices and more contents than the previous ones.5) if this is the first time you play that kind of games at all , in my opinion it would be the best start.-Awesome game , i personally had enjoyed it , and i'd always recommend it with either full or discount price. 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2013
												I'm surprised just how similar Tropico 4 is to it's predecessor Tropico 3. Infact I'd say apart from the graphics the game is almost identical.It's not a bad thing necessarily. Tropico 3 was a very good game in my opinion. However if deciding between this or it's predecessor 3, It's recommended to get the cheaper one since they're basically the same game.Granted Tropico 4 does have a lot more DLC that spices things up so that could be the counterbalance. But in general the game also suffers from the same problems Tropico 3 had. Namely the more casualised aspects of the Sim gameplay. Especially compared to Tropico 1 and 2.So if you enjoy a casual sim game where you play either a despot or a wealthy ruler, Tropico 4 is probably the one to go with. But if you want a game with more to it, look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												For the most part Tropico 4 is one of the first management games I've played in a while. I had a pretty massive gap with the my last really intense period of playing games from this genre involving Rollercoaster Tycoon and Theme Hospital, man those were some great games, then in the last few years I flirted with Football Manager before getting Cities in Motion and Tropico 4. What really drew me into Tropico 4 though is the theme and world that it built. While doing such world building isn't unique in management games, the world that Tropico 4 had built was. I was just really intrigued by the fact that you could attempt to embody some of the worst dictators in human history like Francois Duvalier or become a revolutionary like Fidel Castro or really be anything in between. I don't doubt that the reason behind this draw I felt to the game was my love for history and politics, so I'm pretty sure that anyone who has similar leanings is going to be drawn into the game much the same way I was.Tropico 4 isn't a game for everyone though. Hell, this entire genre isn't for everyone. At the end of the day the entire management genre is just spread sheet management and its your affinity with the world and theme the developers work on that is the reason you actually engage with it. All I can say for certain is that I really like the game, I enjoyed the use of real dictators, the work that was put into the music and art in the game and the fact that game as a whole doesn't take itself serious with all the characters in the game and its campaign being caricature of various historical figure. But I can definitely see that anyone who has no political or historical interests just won't find this game interesting at all and would lean towards another management game based on their interests.If you want to read a longer review of the game you can check it out on my blog: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/08/tropico-4.html.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												To get this gem on sale with all the DLC is one of the better investments on steam you can make. It remains the most in-depth and rewarding Tropico game to date and is a contender for the best city builder title on the market. Great music, real customization, loads of content, freedom with very lax limitations, unique role-play opportunities that promotes a lot of replayability; which overall easily beats the previous and follow-up titles that are a bit lacking in comparison.Rating: 8.5/10

												Made my costum character named Donald Trump. My rise to power was smooth no resistance from my people. And i did what i promised i closed the "borders", put more money into the army and economy. Untill i had no more left, i started asking my good Russian friends for some more.  And they delivered. As a good will i spoke some praise of them and how the west was evil. Russia and i become good Tropical friends. The Russians loved my islands coffee and cigars.Then started having problems with to many jobs and to little people on my small island. Meanwhile the world economy of coffee collapsed and my debts would go up. In the end the Americans invaded my New America. Awesome game if you get the hang of it. 8/10 would want get to invaded by the USA again.

Really a great game, the DLC Modern Times will let you play with even more buildings and options. This DLC is higly recommended. It gives 12 more scenarios.

												I suck at this game.  So let's just get that out of the way, I'm TERRIBLE at this game.  But I love it, it's a blast.  Whether I'm dropping a condo onto a shanty town or I'm hiking the prices of medical care through the roof, life as a dictator is sweet.There are a ton of missions, each with altering goals but the same game play. It's a great game in a similar style as the city simulations, but with a ton of great humor mixed in.  I found myself regularly grinning and laughing at things I'd hear them say on the radio or to my dictator.

												This game had intrigued me with its ads but I wasn't sure if it was worth a buy. Finally I got a good sale on it and was stoked to give it a shot. Sure enough this game is fantastic. Definetely has the same feel as other city building games but with some layers of complexity that feel really nice. Instead of putting you in a world that doesn't really make sense or is obviously fictional they give you something that could actually be plausible. I never knew I would enjoy playing the part of a island dictator but sure enough it's an original enough idea that I have been hooked for hours now. If you are on the fence about this game I would say definetely give it a try. If you enjoy games like Simcity or Banished it felt like a mix of the two with extra polital elements tacked on.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Tropico 4: Steam Special Edition is the first game from Tropico series I have played. Here are my likes and dislikes:Pros:- Great sense of humor (no matter if you are interested in politic related issues or not the humor is great! building descriptions, radio messages, advisors, missions all are really funny - even for an adult player). - A decent graphic with a very detailed zoom-in option- 3-scale game speed up option - I usualy play in the fastest game mode - a wide variety of buildings - a lot of industrial buildings, tourist attractions, housing and social facilities and governmental institutions- interesting economy and political mechanisms -> as the el-presidente you make very important decisions (concerning economy, defence, external or interial policy, education etc.) and you can see what are the effects of your choices- factions - citizens in your island are diveded into a few major factions (religious, nationalists, communist etc.). Your job is to make them happy... or make them be quit :) - a lot of ways you can deal with unhappy citizens - you can bribe one, arrest him/her, arrange accident :) etc. - Music -> you can't hold your feet calm while playing to this caribbean music :)Cons: - a little bit similar development pattern - as the objectives in every mission are different, there is a very similar pattern to complete them. You need a lot of money. You can either develop your industry or invest in tourism. However, once you will find the pattern you like the most you do the same thing in every mission. All over again. - Bugged mission 18 (however bug doesn't occur always) - music - at the beginning you really like it... but after some time you discover that there are just 3 or 4 songs.... for hours of playing way too little. - it is difficult to lose the game - I am in mission 19 and so far I haven't lost one single game (although I needed to restart one mission :P )Finally, my opinion is... you definately should buy this game. If you enjoy strategy games based on economy and political grounds it is something for you. After hours of playing there is always something new you haven't seen yet. And after all, it is so fun to be El Presidente :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Fun and immersive citybuilder in an original and colorful setting. Including the expansion and all the DLC the amount of things to do is almost endless and even without a discount the price is still very reasonable.Both graphically and gameplaywise T4 does lean heavily on its predecessor while being only slightly better, so you can skip part 3 altogether if you haven't played either one of them. To me Tropico 4 is the true followup to the original Tropico from 2001. In fact, I would even recommend this over Tropico 5. If you're a longtime fan of the series, you will probably find T4 more to your liking. While T5 takes an interesting new turn with dynasties and eras, T4 just feels more true to the idea behind the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I have not played Tropico 1 or 2, I started with 3 and loved it. Once again Tropico delivers a fantastic city builder / economic management game and for those of you who have played Tropico 3, you will find that in terms of the interface and the graphics, not a great deal has changed. The graphics are slighty prettier (but then they were pretty good in 3 imho) and there are a couple of tweaks to the interface that might take 30 seconds or so to get used to, but thats about it.What it does bring however, is more depth in terms of gameplay and a more story orientated campaign to play through. There are a number of new buildings which have been introduced with their own functions, but for me the biggest improvement in the gameplay is the way the scenarios work. When campaign missions are initially presented, it isnt like 3 where you have to hit a specific goal or goals persay, more that in order to reach your goals you will have to fulfill and complete a number of in game missions in order to win the scenario. Along side this are a vast number of other missions that will pop up, which if you complete might award you money, faction respect, foreign power respect etc etc; you get the idea. This makes playing through the campaign (and even doing the sandbox island) a lot more fun.I have only 2 minor complaints; I wish the stats that you are presented in the almanac could be drilled down into more. I love stats and being able to have a little more depth would be great. The second, is that I miss the radio DJ from Tropico 3 :( On a final note, I would totally reccomend that anyone buying this (especially if you are coming off the back of Tropico 3) would do well to have a look at one or two of the guides available on steam. When I started I found that I was playing as if it was tropico 3 and not really utilising all the buildings and infrastructre very well. Looking at the guides help me understand certain aspects of the game better and also highlight why certain things I tried didnt work etc.Anyway, I love this game.10/10

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												A very interesting take on a country building / management game where strategy is the key. The array of buildings is quite impressive and the city decor is in ample supply with everything you need to make your mark on your carribean island. You can be a democratic leader giving your citizens all their rights, or become a tyrant and run a submissive country. BEWRAE TYRANTS!! You will make enemies in the form of rebels :) So Bon appetite. This game has decent game mechanics and has quite a in depth feel to it with a strong submerssive experience. You get to get involved in the politics, running of industry's, a commander, and an economic guru whilst all the while keeping relations happy with the U.S.A, U.S.S.R, China, Europe and the Middle East. When I bought it, I bought it on a whim and for a bargain price to at the time and now after many hours I can say its been very much worth it and I still haven't completed it or got bored with it. It could do with some glitches and bugs that could be fixed but they aren't that frequent I have found when playing. Also the game mechanics could be tweaked a little more and have even more building options. Thats just me being picky and my personal preference. I highly rate and recommend this game to anyone who is into this kind of genre. I will continue to keep playing it for many more hours. Nice work Kalypso :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Tropico 4: Steam Special Edition is the first game from Tropico series I have played. Here are my likes and dislikes:Pros:- Great sense of humor (no matter if you are interested in politic related issues or not the humor is great! building descriptions, radio messages, advisors, missions all are really funny - even for an adult player). - A decent graphic with a very detailed zoom-in option- 3-scale game speed up option - I usualy play in the fastest game mode - a wide variety of buildings - a lot of industrial buildings, tourist attractions, housing and social facilities and governmental institutions- interesting economy and political mechanisms -> as the el-presidente you make very important decisions (concerning economy, defence, external or interial policy, education etc.) and you can see what are the effects of your choices- factions - citizens in your island are diveded into a few major factions (religious, nationalists, communist etc.). Your job is to make them happy... or make them be quit :) - a lot of ways you can deal with unhappy citizens - you can bribe one, arrest him/her, arrange accident :) etc. - Music -> you can't hold your feet calm while playing to this caribbean music :)Cons: - a little bit similar development pattern - as the objectives in every mission are different, there is a very similar pattern to complete them. You need a lot of money. You can either develop your industry or invest in tourism. However, once you will find the pattern you like the most you do the same thing in every mission. All over again. - Bugged mission 18 (however bug doesn't occur always) - music - at the beginning you really like it... but after some time you discover that there are just 3 or 4 songs.... for hours of playing way too little. - it is difficult to lose the game - I am in mission 19 and so far I haven't lost one single game (although I needed to restart one mission :P )Finally, my opinion is... you definately should buy this game. If you enjoy strategy games based on economy and political grounds it is something for you. After hours of playing there is always something new you haven't seen yet. And after all, it is so fun to be El Presidente :P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Tropico 4 is a great, in-depth look at how to manage and run a city and its economy. It differs to that of SimCity and Anno as the economy and the needs of the citizens are of great importance to succeeding; imagine running a Sim household translated to city scenario, with the different aspects of society affecting citizen happiness. It's very humourous and can be considered a great introuction to the city building/simulation genre. With the addition of the multiple factions in the game, including the rebels and foregin powers, you further have to micro-manage your expenses and make sure the right people are pleased. The game did teach me about the numerous factions which can be approriated to real life such as nationalists, commuinists, capitalists, loyalists etc, which adds, for lack of a better term, political realism to the game. You really get a hands on feel to what commodities are being produced, where you are generating money, and where you are losing it, with the aid of an Almanac displaying the numerical statatics of your city for easy referral. You dont feel seperated or alienated during the city building process as you are constantly being advised by the numerous, quirky characters, especially your loyally passionate, animated PA, and you do feel like your actions are being counted on which adds an additional layer of immersion. The soundtrack is EXCELLENT, albeit short (which therefore means you can hear you favourite track again shortly :D), with catchy jives and upbeat tempos as the tropican culture is captured perfectly and you do really feel like El Presidente amongst all the exotic instrumentation. The tutorial could have been further in-depth with explaining certain features as I had to resort to googling some aspects, but overall the campaign is great and it feels very rewarding when your exports return an enromous profit bringing you out of debt :P. The way in which the campaign is structured with individual missions means you can schedule and pace your gaming time, instead of wondering when the end is in sight. The different avenues of money-making, i.e. the numerous exporting commodities, means you can differ your stragety each time you play a mission, without routine-like, repeting methods. With the specific, analytical nature of the gameplay, you aren't looking at expansive, sprawling cities and skylines, so this game does create an attractive niche in the genre without detracting purpose to playing other mainstream city building games. I havent played the dlc campaigns yet, but in addition to that you get more outfit options for your avatar and decorations,  I wouldn't count them as must-have additions, the campaign dlc would probably be sufficient. I'm really keen to check out Tropico 5 now and see how it differs and what new features are implemented. Grabbing Tropico 4 (presumably the Steam Special Edition) for under $10 is well worth it, no buyers remorse. Overall, I rate this game 4 out of 5 spainards.(Forgive the long review, it's 4:30am and I'm carelessly indulging in my BA knowlege, I need sleep.)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Not having played any other game in the series, getting into Tropico 4 I was afraid of running face first into a learning curve wall, but was pleasantly surprised by the way the game was designed. It's intuitive and does a good job at explaining the core mechanics without holding your hand whilst talking down to you.What I mean is that Tropico 4 is extremely accessible. You almost cannot lose unless you overreach something fierce. Even then, you can tell when things aren't working out, and you're more often than not given time to rectify the situation. The difficulty lies in the unique stipulations and events of each individual scenario, which actually switches the gameplay up to the point where you get to work with all your tools and not just do the same build over and over. I appreciate that, because it's a welcome change of pace from a lot of other strategy games where you just find "the best" way to play and then repeat until the end credits.The ambience and tone of the game is spot on for what it goes for, keeping it light and humorous. It's chock-full of caricatured and satirized references to real life leaders and personalities, with plenty of jokes and easter eggs to keeps you entertained even when the gameplay starts getting repetetive and slow. Graphically, it's ok without being especially impressive. Thankfully it's not going for impressive, though, but rather functionally, which it is. You can run it on most systems without any problems. Everything's clear and you won't have any problems getting into the mood of the game.If you're an achievement hunter looking for another perfect clear, be aware that some of the "harder" achievements are rare because they're incredibly grind-heavy. I got stuck playing the same sandbox map over and over for more than 20 games after having cleared the campaigns, in order to get all character traits to level 5. Took hours and wasn't much fun after a while, although I hadn't maximized my char traits beforehand so some levels had been wasted.When it comes to DLC, I would actually advice against getting "Modern Times", since the buildings you get completely break the game. You will get stuff that just replaces everything you can get in the base game, and all difficulty is thrown out the window. It could be fun for a couple of games or a long sandbox game, but it'll get tired and it'll get tired fast. Just isn't worth it in my opinion.In conclusion, I warmly recommend it. Tropico 4 is a game that'll keep you busy for hours on end, and keep you entertained throughout. It's got character, atmosphere and tongue-in-cheek satire. It immerses you in the world of banana republics and continuously challenges you with new and innovative problems. Just don't bother with the "Modern Times" DLC, as it kind of breaks the flow of the game and makes it much too easy and simple. If it's on sale, get it! If it's not, but you like city builder strategy games, why not pick it up?

												This game is amazing if you're willing to invest the time to learn from it.  It's not only a great city building / politics hybrid game, but there's a lot of humor as well.  The soundtrack is very authentic and enjoyable and all in spanish, but very catchy and sets the mood well.  The campaign is very interesting throughout all 20 missions, this is a game that can make you lose track of time, Civ 5 style.  Once you learn the basic controls and how to setup your initial economy, you'll be hooked on this game and want to fire up a big ol' cigar!  Get this game if you've liked simcity type games, but always wondered what would happen if you could rig elections, eliminate threats, and build bigass statues of yourself.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Tropico 4 doesn’t reinvent the wheel but it certainly polishes it up. The gameplay is simple enough to learn but complex enough to keep you occupied.  Disasters, faction challenges, foreign powers and story objectives make the game even more challenging. The game is rife with political and social commentary that may provide a chuckle or two. The soundtrack is enjoyable even though it’s fairly repetitive. It should be noted that the population limit is low compared to other city sims and roads are easily congested due the lack of multiple lane highways. Still, these are only minor frustrations in an otherwise entertaining game nonetheless! Pick up the Modern Times expansion if you can!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Welcome to the fourth installment of the popular 'Tropico' franchise. Highly acclaimed with a ton of rave reviews, but is this game as good as people say? Yes. Yes it is.If you are new to the Tropico franchise like I was, then here is a very quick rundown of the game:You are El Presidente, the leader of a small Carribean 'paradise' called Tropico. Your main aim is to transform Tropico, an underdeveloped and practically lifeless bunch of Islands, into a world superpower by any and all means necessary. You will  straight up notice some very funny parallels to the real world as Tropico is basically Cuba, and El Presidente is based off a number of socialist and communist figures such as Fidel Castro and Che Guevera. Throughout the campaigns in the game you will have total control over Tropico which will see you lead your state onto the international platform for either good, or bad reasons. You will need to balance your popularity with your people by pleasing the various factions present within your society; something that is easier said than done. Similarly, you need to stay on the right side of the world superpowers as the game is based during the Cold War and your decisions will vary your popularity with the United States of America (US), or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). There are other world leaders but they don't threaten to invade you, well, as far as i'm aware anyway. Alongside all of this, you must work to transform Tropico by investing money into things like housing, welfare, food and resources, government, tourism, etc. Make sure you don't blow your budget too badly though because the world superpowers don't like broke countries. Also, prepare for major natural disasters that will kill your people, ruin your buildings and crops.Some people may read this and say 'This is just a mix of the Sims/Cities mixed with Democracy or something like that'. In a way maybe it is, but here is why I think Tropico is way better. Political corruption is encouraged in the game. Need to get more products out? Run a sweatshop. Rebels annoying you? Wire tap houses, impose martial law, conscript citizens into your army against their will. Getting too many immigrants and have shacks overunning your beautiful paradise? Force emigration. Faction leader or protesters becoming too popular? Have them eliminated or arrested for herecy. Minister of Foreign Affairs made a bad decision? Fire him and arrest him. . . See what I mean? How does this not sound fun?If you like being the corrupt leader of Cuba and focusing more on being famous than the wellbeing of your citizens who you can force to never leave a state with poor housing, bad health conditions, slave labour, conscription, propeganda, rebels, frequent natural disasters, and 'accidents' or disappearences happening way too reguarly.. than this is the game for you.Buy it. Play it. Live it.TROPICO 4.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I have not played Tropico 1 or 2, I started with 3 and loved it. Once again Tropico delivers a fantastic city builder / economic management game and for those of you who have played Tropico 3, you will find that in terms of the interface and the graphics, not a great deal has changed. The graphics are slighty prettier (but then they were pretty good in 3 imho) and there are a couple of tweaks to the interface that might take 30 seconds or so to get used to, but thats about it.What it does bring however, is more depth in terms of gameplay and a more story orientated campaign to play through. There are a number of new buildings which have been introduced with their own functions, but for me the biggest improvement in the gameplay is the way the scenarios work. When campaign missions are initially presented, it isnt like 3 where you have to hit a specific goal or goals persay, more that in order to reach your goals you will have to fulfill and complete a number of in game missions in order to win the scenario. Along side this are a vast number of other missions that will pop up, which if you complete might award you money, faction respect, foreign power respect etc etc; you get the idea. This makes playing through the campaign (and even doing the sandbox island) a lot more fun.I have only 2 minor complaints; I wish the stats that you are presented in the almanac could be drilled down into more. I love stats and being able to have a little more depth would be great. The second, is that I miss the radio DJ from Tropico 3 :( On a final note, I would totally reccomend that anyone buying this (especially if you are coming off the back of Tropico 3) would do well to have a look at one or two of the guides available on steam. When I started I found that I was playing as if it was tropico 3 and not really utilising all the buildings and infrastructre very well. Looking at the guides help me understand certain aspects of the game better and also highlight why certain things I tried didnt work etc.Anyway, I love this game.10/10

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Tropico 4: Steam Special Edition is the first game from Tropico series I have played. Here are my likes and dislikes:Pros:- Great sense of humor (no matter if you are interested in politic related issues or not the humor is great! building descriptions, radio messages, advisors, missions all are really funny - even for an adult player). - A decent graphic with a very detailed zoom-in option- 3-scale game speed up option - I usualy play in the fastest game mode - a wide variety of buildings - a lot of industrial buildings, tourist attractions, housing and social facilities and governmental institutions- interesting economy and political mechanisms -> as the el-presidente you make very important decisions (concerning economy, defence, external or interial policy, education etc.) and you can see what are the effects of your choices- factions - citizens in your island are diveded into a few major factions (religious, nationalists, communist etc.). Your job is to make them happy... or make them be quit :) - a lot of ways you can deal with unhappy citizens - you can bribe one, arrest him/her, arrange accident :) etc. - Music -> you can't hold your feet calm while playing to this caribbean music :)Cons: - a little bit similar development pattern - as the objectives in every mission are different, there is a very similar pattern to complete them. You need a lot of money. You can either develop your industry or invest in tourism. However, once you will find the pattern you like the most you do the same thing in every mission. All over again. - Bugged mission 18 (however bug doesn't occur always) - music - at the beginning you really like it... but after some time you discover that there are just 3 or 4 songs.... for hours of playing way too little. - it is difficult to lose the game - I am in mission 19 and so far I haven't lost one single game (although I needed to restart one mission :P )Finally, my opinion is... you definately should buy this game. If you enjoy strategy games based on economy and political grounds it is something for you. After hours of playing there is always something new you haven't seen yet. And after all, it is so fun to be El Presidente :P

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014

Well for starters it's your average city building simulator, except you know you're a cold war dictator, that being said, having absolute power does have it's perks, from arraging elections, building labor camps, and making people quietly dissaper. 												A very interesting take on a country building / management game where strategy is the key. The array of buildings is quite impressive and the city decor is in ample supply with everything you need to make your mark on your carribean island. You can be a democratic leader giving your citizens all their rights, or become a tyrant and run a submissive country. BEWRAE TYRANTS!! You will make enemies in the form of rebels :) So Bon appetite. This game has decent game mechanics and has quite a in depth feel to it with a strong submerssive experience. You get to get involved in the politics, running of industry's, a commander, and an economic guru whilst all the while keeping relations happy with the U.S.A, U.S.S.R, China, Europe and the Middle East. When I bought it, I bought it on a whim and for a bargain price to at the time and now after many hours I can say its been very much worth it and I still haven't completed it or got bored with it. It could do with some glitches and bugs that could be fixed but they aren't that frequent I have found when playing. Also the game mechanics could be tweaked a little more and have even more building options. Thats just me being picky and my personal preference. I highly rate and recommend this game to anyone who is into this kind of genre. I will continue to keep playing it for many more hours. Nice work Kalypso :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												Welcome to the fourth installment of the popular 'Tropico' franchise. Highly acclaimed with a ton of rave reviews, but is this game as good as people say? Yes. Yes it is.If you are new to the Tropico franchise like I was, then here is a very quick rundown of the game:You are El Presidente, the leader of a small Carribean 'paradise' called Tropico. Your main aim is to transform Tropico, an underdeveloped and practically lifeless bunch of Islands, into a world superpower by any and all means necessary. You will  straight up notice some very funny parallels to the real world as Tropico is basically Cuba, and El Presidente is based off a number of socialist and communist figures such as Fidel Castro and Che Guevera. Throughout the campaigns in the game you will have total control over Tropico which will see you lead your state onto the international platform for either good, or bad reasons. You will need to balance your popularity with your people by pleasing the various factions present within your society; something that is easier said than done. Similarly, you need to stay on the right side of the world superpowers as the game is based during the Cold War and your decisions will vary your popularity with the United States of America (US), or the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). There are other world leaders but they don't threaten to invade you, well, as far as i'm aware anyway. Alongside all of this, you must work to transform Tropico by investing money into things like housing, welfare, food and resources, government, tourism, etc. Make sure you don't blow your budget too badly though because the world superpowers don't like broke countries. Also, prepare for major natural disasters that will kill your people, ruin your buildings and crops.Some people may read this and say 'This is just a mix of the Sims/Cities mixed with Democracy or something like that'. In a way maybe it is, but here is why I think Tropico is way better. Political corruption is encouraged in the game. Need to get more products out? Run a sweatshop. Rebels annoying you? Wire tap houses, impose martial law, conscript citizens into your army against their will. Getting too many immigrants and have shacks overunning your beautiful paradise? Force emigration. Faction leader or protesters becoming too popular? Have them eliminated or arrested for herecy. Minister of Foreign Affairs made a bad decision? Fire him and arrest him. . . See what I mean? How does this not sound fun?If you like being the corrupt leader of Cuba and focusing more on being famous than the wellbeing of your citizens who you can force to never leave a state with poor housing, bad health conditions, slave labour, conscription, propeganda, rebels, frequent natural disasters, and 'accidents' or disappearences happening way too reguarly.. than this is the game for you.Buy it. Play it. Live it.TROPICO 4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Not having played any other game in the series, getting into Tropico 4 I was afraid of running face first into a learning curve wall, but was pleasantly surprised by the way the game was designed. It's intuitive and does a good job at explaining the core mechanics without holding your hand whilst talking down to you.What I mean is that Tropico 4 is extremely accessible. You almost cannot lose unless you overreach something fierce. Even then, you can tell when things aren't working out, and you're more often than not given time to rectify the situation. The difficulty lies in the unique stipulations and events of each individual scenario, which actually switches the gameplay up to the point where you get to work with all your tools and not just do the same build over and over. I appreciate that, because it's a welcome change of pace from a lot of other strategy games where you just find "the best" way to play and then repeat until the end credits.The ambience and tone of the game is spot on for what it goes for, keeping it light and humorous. It's chock-full of caricatured and satirized references to real life leaders and personalities, with plenty of jokes and easter eggs to keeps you entertained even when the gameplay starts getting repetetive and slow. Graphically, it's ok without being especially impressive. Thankfully it's not going for impressive, though, but rather functionally, which it is. You can run it on most systems without any problems. Everything's clear and you won't have any problems getting into the mood of the game.If you're an achievement hunter looking for another perfect clear, be aware that some of the "harder" achievements are rare because they're incredibly grind-heavy. I got stuck playing the same sandbox map over and over for more than 20 games after having cleared the campaigns, in order to get all character traits to level 5. Took hours and wasn't much fun after a while, although I hadn't maximized my char traits beforehand so some levels had been wasted.When it comes to DLC, I would actually advice against getting "Modern Times", since the buildings you get completely break the game. You will get stuff that just replaces everything you can get in the base game, and all difficulty is thrown out the window. It could be fun for a couple of games or a long sandbox game, but it'll get tired and it'll get tired fast. Just isn't worth it in my opinion.In conclusion, I warmly recommend it. Tropico 4 is a game that'll keep you busy for hours on end, and keep you entertained throughout. It's got character, atmosphere and tongue-in-cheek satire. It immerses you in the world of banana republics and continuously challenges you with new and innovative problems. Just don't bother with the "Modern Times" DLC, as it kind of breaks the flow of the game and makes it much too easy and simple. If it's on sale, get it! If it's not, but you like city builder strategy games, why not pick it up?

content:
Posted: December 28, 2011
												If you've never played a Tropico game before, this is the one to get. If you already have Tropico 3 though, you might want to wait until Tropico 4's price goes down to $10 or $15, since the game is largely an expansion of Tropico 3. Still, the new elements of Tropico 4 are considerably fun.The most noticable difference is the 'trait levelling' system. As you play through the game, you'll gain experience in your chosen traits and start levelling them up, improving their beneficial effects. This adds a lot of replay value to the game, since it encourages you to pick different traits for your avatar and try playing with them in order to improve them, rather than simply picking a single set of traits you favor early on and never changing them.Tropico 4 also adds deeper levels of political intrigue; along with Tropico's usual internal factions and Cold War sabre-rattling between the US and USSR, there's now the European Union, China, and the Middle East.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												This game is really great and you should buy it.First, the cons: - There's a bit of a curve in figuring out exactly what the people think is reasonable (for example, protip: housing prices should be 1/3 of the person's salary, rounded down, and entertainment should be exactly their salary). - The missions are very scripted and the gameplay very freeform, resulting in occasional basically-guaranteed losses or complete non-challenges after you complete an objective and the next impossible-to-predict-the-first-time-trying scripted event occurs. - Being a tyrant is really underpowered vs. being totally nice and helpful.Besides that, this game is packed with wit, charm, and fun. Tropico 3 was just a remake of Tropico 1, but this game really takes strides in perfecting the forumula. Any good sim-builder needs lots of knobs and buttons to fiddle with, and this game has a bunch of them - and best of all, they're generally not packed painfully into drab numerical menus. There are no up and down buttons for employment; you actually click a socket for a worker's face to close it off and limit how many people the building will employ. This and *actually helpful* tooltips (some devs get it wrong, somehow) make the game immediately accessible. You'll have your work cut out for you balancing the desires of the various factions, and who you decide to please and who you decide to push to the brink of rebellion will often depend entirely on the resources of the island and your mission objectives. A huge problem with most games of this genre is the tendency for a single strategy to win every time; while this is still present in Tropico 4 to some degree, the missions are crafted carefully enough, with enough special conditions to disrupt your winning strategies, that it's less of a problem here than in any other game I've ever played in this genre.The writing in the game is top-notch and if you don't find yourself smirking from time to time at the bald-faced satire, then you need to get your sense of humor checked out. This game finds creative ways to poke fun at cold-war banana republics, stereotypes, popular video games, and more. At no point do you feel guilty for being a big, stupid tyrant, because all the international powers are bigger, stupider, and more tyrannical. This gives a fun sense of empathy to El Presidente despite his self-serving nature, and motivates you to shelter the helpless people of Tropico from the uncaring ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on both sides of the iron curtain... and maybe launder some tax money as payment while you're doing them the service.I can't recommend this game highly enough. I've bought all the DLC and earned every achievement because I can't get enough of El Presidente. If you're actually considering this game enough to be here reading reviews about it, do yourself a favor and go for it.

content:

												Fun and immersive citybuilder in an original and colorful setting. Including the expansion and all the DLC the amount of things to do is almost endless and even without a discount the price is still very reasonable.Both graphically and gameplaywise T4 does lean heavily on its predecessor while being only slightly better, so you can skip part 3 altogether if you haven't played either one of them. To me Tropico 4 is the true followup to the original Tropico from 2001. In fact, I would even recommend this over Tropico 5. If you're a longtime fan of the series, you will probably find T4 more to your liking. While T5 takes an interesting new turn with dynasties and eras, T4 just feels more true to the idea behind the series.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
Product received for free
												E' il primo tropico che provo e il gioco, se piace il genere, ti regala diverse soddisfazioni. Non l'ho preso prima perchè non lo conoscevo e grazie ad un sito l'ho preso gratis. Tropico 4 si presenta ben strutturato e con vari tipi di gioco possibili rendendo la longevità strettamente collegata all'immaginazione del giocatore. In che senso? Nel senso che, oltre ad offrire un bel po' di isole dove costruire la tua cittadina, ti offre anche numerosi metodi per fare crescere la tua isola sotto il punto di vista demografico ed economico. Possiamo benissimo paragonarlo alla realtà; Vogliamo puntare sul turismo? Bene valorizziamo il territorio, vogliamo puntare sullo sfruttamento della mano d'opera stile multinazionale sanguisughe? Bene potete. Quindi la durata e soprattutto il gusto di giocarci varia da giocatore a giocatore ed in base a come decide di comportarsi, è ovvio che un giocatore molto metodico che punta sempre sugli stessi fattori si annoierà prima rispetto ad un altro che preferisce uno stile di gioco più vario e ricco di sorprese. La grafica è senza infamia e senza lode, ma per gli appassionati del genere si sa, non è cosi rilevante come lo sarebbe in un fps perchè le priorità sono, ovviamente, altre.Consigliato!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Not having played any other game in the series, getting into Tropico 4 I was afraid of running face first into a learning curve wall, but was pleasantly surprised by the way the game was designed. It's intuitive and does a good job at explaining the core mechanics without holding your hand whilst talking down to you.What I mean is that Tropico 4 is extremely accessible. You almost cannot lose unless you overreach something fierce. Even then, you can tell when things aren't working out, and you're more often than not given time to rectify the situation. The difficulty lies in the unique stipulations and events of each individual scenario, which actually switches the gameplay up to the point where you get to work with all your tools and not just do the same build over and over. I appreciate that, because it's a welcome change of pace from a lot of other strategy games where you just find "the best" way to play and then repeat until the end credits.The ambience and tone of the game is spot on for what it goes for, keeping it light and humorous. It's chock-full of caricatured and satirized references to real life leaders and personalities, with plenty of jokes and easter eggs to keeps you entertained even when the gameplay starts getting repetetive and slow. Graphically, it's ok without being especially impressive. Thankfully it's not going for impressive, though, but rather functionally, which it is. You can run it on most systems without any problems. Everything's clear and you won't have any problems getting into the mood of the game.If you're an achievement hunter looking for another perfect clear, be aware that some of the "harder" achievements are rare because they're incredibly grind-heavy. I got stuck playing the same sandbox map over and over for more than 20 games after having cleared the campaigns, in order to get all character traits to level 5. Took hours and wasn't much fun after a while, although I hadn't maximized my char traits beforehand so some levels had been wasted.When it comes to DLC, I would actually advice against getting "Modern Times", since the buildings you get completely break the game. You will get stuff that just replaces everything you can get in the base game, and all difficulty is thrown out the window. It could be fun for a couple of games or a long sandbox game, but it'll get tired and it'll get tired fast. Just isn't worth it in my opinion.In conclusion, I warmly recommend it. Tropico 4 is a game that'll keep you busy for hours on end, and keep you entertained throughout. It's got character, atmosphere and tongue-in-cheek satire. It immerses you in the world of banana republics and continuously challenges you with new and innovative problems. Just don't bother with the "Modern Times" DLC, as it kind of breaks the flow of the game and makes it much too easy and simple. If it's on sale, get it! If it's not, but you like city builder strategy games, why not pick it up?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Vote El Presidente... Or else!Tropico is one of those games that make you appreciate the fact that smaller companies create so good games!Well,the task in this game is quite simple, rule your island as the Dictator, El Presidente, keep the political relations with the other nations to a good level, provide food, work, housing and other important needs for your fellow followers, listen to some of your(at some points) terribly annoying advisors! And last, but not least- Lead TROPICO to the Glory.Alright, this might not sound particularly interesting for many of you, I assume... sounds like yet another boring strategy game, right? Well... actually no. There is so much more to it than meets the eye, hidden in the small details that make this game unique:-The set and atmosphere: You are on a tropical island, Earth's paradise, never before seen beauty. The perfect place to become a dictator! The islands are made so beautifully, it really sets you in the relaxing mood of the tropical culture, so to speak. It is just beautiful to look at, from any angle. The palm trees, the small animals, the buildings(some of which are hilarious), the cars(honestly, I love the design of the cars.. like come on.. who wouldnt drive a car like that in real life? I certainly would!!), and all other small details make up for a really sweet game.-The soundtrack: Now, as I said before, the atmosphere is just amazing. But hold on there, buddy!! It gets even better when the music starts playing. You felt like you are on the island before the music started? Ha, just wait till the music starts, you don't feel like...YOU ARE on the island, right there, just by the Palace of El Prez, listening to his speech regarding the last elections, which he won with the stunning 96% of votes, of course... his opponent went missing after that, Penultimo gave him a ticket to go to a vacation you know... there's nothing more to that.Beautiful soundtrack! They picked the music perfectly. It's one of the best out there for me personally. What better way to cheer yourself up than with some latino music, dances and songs!!!!!! Yaaaay!-The gameplay: simple, yet a little harder to master! Build buildings, get more people on the island, pray not to run out of money- profit out of it.Thing is, you need a strong economy early on, otherwise you will quickly run out of money. Start building tourist spots and them pesky tourists will just pour and pour money in El Presidente's Swiss Bank Account- that is all he needs to know! Build better housing for your citizens, pay them more when you earn more money, make them happy, win the next elections!Or just leave things as they are, gain a few rebels here and there, issue martial law, screw elections, survive an assassination attempt and keep ruling this beautiful nation that Tropico is! It is up to you! But beware, US ans USSR's ships are always seeking for that one moment to invade your country. El Prez must react fast! Quick, Penultimo, build that nuclear program.All in all, this is a fantastic game if you want to spend some free time gaming and to chill after a rough day! It makes you have fun and be happy.I have spent hundreds of hours on it on a non-steam version, and, believe me, every time i come back, I find something new. And this is what I cherish in Tropico!I strongly recommend this game to everyone

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
Product received for free
												Gameplay, Tropico 4 doesn't delve too far from the generic mechanics of a city building simulation genre. You manage your city/nation's economy, monitor the population, provide housing, food, services and employment, and construct buildings for some of their other needs such as healthcare and spirituality. The definitive characteristic of this one's you'll be tasked to focus on one island and only one island at a time (unlike in Anno where you can build on other nearby islands, here, other islands are almost non-existent). There's also balance on this one in terms of freedom on how you want to run your island. You have options on where to run your economy, be it Tourism or other forms of industry chains.Another strong selling point of this game's the dialogue, the humor is strong in this one. I hope I can also befriend someone from the Middle East who promises me a camel but sends me 30,000 USD on my way instead. Something his wives found while cleaning the couch.Visuals, score and other things, nothing really stands out here.So, yeah. I'd give this one a commend. Buy the DLC's too, if you can. I heard they make the game a little more rounded with options.Camels/10 will be a dictator again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Bursting at the seams with charming, satirical humour and a kickass caribbean/hispanic soundtrack, Tropico 4puts the players in the shoes of El Presidente, newly appointed leader of the island nation of Tropico. As el Presidente, the player can choose to govern the island in whatever manner as he/she pleases.The game mostly plays out as a kind of city sim, but with more/less complexity in some departments. On the political side of things, as El Presidente, you are in charge of the government's local and foreign policies, appointing ministers and even building your own army/glorified bodyguard force. However, the city-building aspects of zoning districts, managing utilities and directing traffic are vastly simplified. Ultimately, the game is an island economy simulator, with everything else existing to supplement it.Whilst the possibilities to play Tropico 4 however you want to play it is endless, the only two playstyles that will bring you any sort of success is to become a relentless industrial capitalist or relentless tourism-focused capitalist. Combine that with the game's huge focus on economy and moneymaking, and the campaign starts feeling repetitive.Hold on though! That is where the game's humour holds up it's otherwise weak campaign. Putting aside the campaign's nonsensical and overly convoluted plot, the characters have large personalities that brilliantly lampoon world leaders and common stereotypes. The characters give Tropico 4 a vibrant personality that is the shining pillar that holds it up above the multitude of other bland, boring city sims/ economy simulators.Like the islands in the game itself, one cannot be too fooled with the outwards image that Tropico 4 projects and ignore the less pretty, less polished inner workings. The interface, while elegantly simple, poorly presents vital data and is far too simple for the task of managing an island. Micromanagement is non-existent. Once your island reaches a critical mass of population, traffic inevitably slows down, frustrating all your plans.While I had fun with Tropico 4, it's many flaws stemming from the repetitive nature of it's fundamental gameplay mechanics holds it back from being a true representation of Caribbean island governance. However, the game's exuberant and charming humour serves to alleviate the lack in gameplay variety and somewhat dated graphics.I mean, who doesn't love El Presidente?  (love El Presidente or else)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ARBITRARY NUMBER RATING : 7.4/10~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Excellent city builder with intrinsic flaws. I love this game, it is a very good city builder sim. A lot of building types compliment and/or require other buildings, so there is a realistic synergy to how to plan and build a city. For instance you can mine ores and simply sell it. Or you could build factories to refine it and make items out of them and sell those. Most commercial building types have complimentary building types.It's a very layered game, but easy enough to get into, for novice or experienced city sim player alike.Downside is that your city will only last for a certain amount of years, but even with that there's usually ample time to develop and play one, and it has a lot of scenario's to play through as well as the ability to create your own scenario's. You can go as long as you want after a scenario ends but eventually cities become very unwieldy.Overall, a very enjoyable city building sim that touches all the bases; resource management, population, political, commerce and trade, natural disasters. It's the whole package, just served up in nice big scenario's to play through. with lots of inexpensive DLC's introducing new building types and scenario's to experiment with. And if you don't like any of those, create your own scenario with your own set of unique goals.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Vote El Presidente... Or else!Tropico is one of those games that make you appreciate the fact that smaller companies create so good games!Well,the task in this game is quite simple, rule your island as the Dictator, El Presidente, keep the political relations with the other nations to a good level, provide food, work, housing and other important needs for your fellow followers, listen to some of your(at some points) terribly annoying advisors! And last, but not least- Lead TROPICO to the Glory.Alright, this might not sound particularly interesting for many of you, I assume... sounds like yet another boring strategy game, right? Well... actually no. There is so much more to it than meets the eye, hidden in the small details that make this game unique:-The set and atmosphere: You are on a tropical island, Earth's paradise, never before seen beauty. The perfect place to become a dictator! The islands are made so beautifully, it really sets you in the relaxing mood of the tropical culture, so to speak. It is just beautiful to look at, from any angle. The palm trees, the small animals, the buildings(some of which are hilarious), the cars(honestly, I love the design of the cars.. like come on.. who wouldnt drive a car like that in real life? I certainly would!!), and all other small details make up for a really sweet game.-The soundtrack: Now, as I said before, the atmosphere is just amazing. But hold on there, buddy!! It gets even better when the music starts playing. You felt like you are on the island before the music started? Ha, just wait till the music starts, you don't feel like...YOU ARE on the island, right there, just by the Palace of El Prez, listening to his speech regarding the last elections, which he won with the stunning 96% of votes, of course... his opponent went missing after that, Penultimo gave him a ticket to go to a vacation you know... there's nothing more to that.Beautiful soundtrack! They picked the music perfectly. It's one of the best out there for me personally. What better way to cheer yourself up than with some latino music, dances and songs!!!!!! Yaaaay!-The gameplay: simple, yet a little harder to master! Build buildings, get more people on the island, pray not to run out of money- profit out of it.Thing is, you need a strong economy early on, otherwise you will quickly run out of money. Start building tourist spots and them pesky tourists will just pour and pour money in El Presidente's Swiss Bank Account- that is all he needs to know! Build better housing for your citizens, pay them more when you earn more money, make them happy, win the next elections!Or just leave things as they are, gain a few rebels here and there, issue martial law, screw elections, survive an assassination attempt and keep ruling this beautiful nation that Tropico is! It is up to you! But beware, US ans USSR's ships are always seeking for that one moment to invade your country. El Prez must react fast! Quick, Penultimo, build that nuclear program.All in all, this is a fantastic game if you want to spend some free time gaming and to chill after a rough day! It makes you have fun and be happy.I have spent hundreds of hours on it on a non-steam version, and, believe me, every time i come back, I find something new. And this is what I cherish in Tropico!I strongly recommend this game to everyone

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
Tropico 4 is a great simulator-construction-management game. Excellent game to build a city on an island of your choice (each island one has a certain degree of difficulty, there are many interesting islands and my choice was not easy). It has several objectives to accomplish and it's very easy to get into debt.The game becomes even more interesting with the various DLC's which add a variety of events in the game (natural disasters like volcanoes, tornadoes or tsunamis, invasions of enemy factions, etc.) and it hardly becomes repetitive; I advise your purchase.The game goes far beyond its dictatorial order, is a true masterpiece at several levels: management, whether territorial, financial and human.+excellent graphics+simple and attractive gameplay+many President's to select+good ways to learn about economy and strategy+unlock of new structures as it moves forward in time+the play of colors in the game is spectacular (weather system)+soundtrack+DLC'sI have fulfilled my desire to be Salazar.My first Tropico game and I could not be more happier.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												If you're a fan of sandbox, builder games, you will like Tropico. Pros: The game itself falls just short of being a perennial, all-time classic. The music is great, the plot is fun, including quasi-historical background. Tons of replayability. Fun for fulfilling all of your dictator fantasies :)Pro and con: Tropico 1 and Tropico 4 are practically the same game. Nothing has changed.Cons: The whole Tropico series lacks a bit of polish that would make it "best-game-ever". Building can be slow, even on the maximum speed. When starting a new scenario, you tend to build the same stuff over and over. Sometimes the consequences/cost-benefit of buildings isn't always clear.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												As much as this game is fun to start with, things can get rather repetitive. The campaign missions provided enough events to hold my attention, aswell as being a reasonable length so I didn't get bored, however after about 15 or so missions I found myself doing the same things over and over when building up the island. The major thing holding this game back is the number of buildings you can construct. The island you are given is far too large to accomodate creativitly and diversity in the construction of your buildings, as there is simply not enough buildings to do so. I've only purchased the original game and no DLC, so it may improve with those but I feel like the base game should at least have double the constructable buildings it has.All in all, I've found the game fun, and would recommend it if you're a city builder fan.

												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I bought this game on an extreme sale not really expecting much other than some cheap entertainment, and I ended up being pleasantly surprised.The player take the role of a South American dictator who undergoes various trials to develop the island nation of Tropico.  You can choose to embrace US-style captialism, Soviet-style communism, or a tourism-based economy.  Your island is home to various competing interests that you must work to satisfy, so there's a lot of things to juggle.  The main campaign is challenging and diverse, I chose to play through that instead of just building stand-alone islands.One of the most unexpected positives of the game is that the campaign is just plain funny.  The banter between your dictator avatar, your advisors, the various diplomats you engage with, and the other NPCs is consistently entertaining, and is a well-written parody of Cold War era foreign relations with Latin America.My wife and I played the game side-by-side and enjoyed bantering about the various levels and the decisions that we made.
