content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
Product received for free
												I was about to thumb it down until I found a way to bypass that 2nd layer DRM....heh. So I guess my thumbs down turned into a thumbs up! Also I just notice on the store page it does say "Incorporates 3rd-party DRM: Requires a free Kalypso account", but I didn't get my copy through steam, rather through Humble Bundle (HB) which I was lucky enough to be browsing through at the time and checking up what's new there and I happen to come accross this[www.humblebundle.com] and thought ooh, free ay...? What's the catch...? - As there's always a catch to free stuff... In this case you needed to redeem the key within 7 days of and of course Tropico looked decent enough to redeem, I didn't want it to be sitting in my library doing nothing.As of this review, you still got eight hours left to go there and get your free copy!As for the game itself, yes I've actually played some of it; I finished the tutorial and finished the first campaign of the 20 there are, I will continue when ever.Game's like a city building type where you manage and micromanage your city. The only game I can relate this to is Emperor: Rise of the Middle Kingdom (E:RotMK) as that's the only other city type building game I've played. If you've never played nor seen that well then basically you either start from scratch or have a preset of buildings/units that's already setup for you and you either build up from there and conquer the world, like in E:RotMK or build the best place to live in via Tropico.I've yet to invade or get invaded in Tropico so I can't comment on that, but with E:RotMK, assuming this game is the same, you can build up an army and go own a city and then they pay you *rent* money, as you now own them, either through hard cold cash or commodities like Silk or Rice that you want/need. So far, I'm at 12/20 of the campagins(i've finished the entire campaign, and still no ability to invade, the army is only there to fight back the rebels and hold order and that's about it.....pretty lame.... I haven't gotten invaded yet by the USSR or the US, but I'm guessing my army protects me from that too and can fend them? So they are able to invade, but I can't invade either? Or even Europe, Chine and the Middle East? LAME!Also so far I've found that they've recycled a couple of the maps in it through out the campaign...yet calling them different island names....which is odd... One of them is the island where there are no bauxite/iron/gold(so only income is import raw materials and export their final products and or tourism) and the other is where there's a temple at the bottom of the map with two gold mines and two iron mines above it and your base is at the top if you adjust the camera so that the bottom map is flush with the minimap view. Ok, now there's three maps that hve been recycled....Also, the ability to find who's unemployed and other details and such would be nice so I can employ them....and or do other stuff with them....And yeah......that's all I want to say about it...I suppose the other part of me forcing the thumbs up rather than keeping it down is that the graphics is decent, I haven't come across any bugs/glitches and that I like the game so far.====================================Played on Raikou (Gigabyte P35x V3): i74710HQ, 16GB RAM, GTX 980M, 128GB and 1TB SSD mSATA, 2TB HDD, Win 7 Pro x64, BD-R ODD, FHD display

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												I had always been curious to try this series and I'm glad that I eventually did. I started off with its third instalment and that got me hooked. This game improves upon an already good formula with its superior graphics, campaign and detail. For those of you who are unfamiliar with the series, think Caribbean city-builder. One of the most appealing things about this game is just its all-round humour. While being a tad childish, you can still get a laugh out of some of the jokes - especially the stereotypes. The game's awesome latin soundtrack is also pretty good too. It's a very self-aware game and that's why I love it. If you've never played a game in the series before, this is where you should start.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												The most basic question from a lot of people when they look into Tropico 4 is this: Is it any better than Tropico 3?Short answer, In some ways yes and in other many sad ways nope. The Tropico series for those who haven't played any Tropico games at all is this. You are a Tin Pot Dictator of a small cluster of fictional Islands in the Carribean. You aim is to get rich stuffing as much money as you can into your off shore Swiss Bank Account and try and not get overthrow by the angry factions you have to appease, the people and finally the angry Cold War era Super Powers. Sounds simple right?But anyways, Tropico 4 versus 3. The general improvements between the two games don't seem massive to be brutally honest. Some of the problems from 3 are still there (triggering Edicts still has no visual effects apart from your bank balance, same graphics and the same damn music) but 4 brings some improvements to the table. It is clear they learnt something from the DLC and Expansion of Tropico 3 as quite a few features have been ported over to the newer game. I'm sure there is  a huge amount of under the hook tweaks and additions that make it a slightly smoother experince from Tropico 3.For one Tropico 4 has a bit more soul and is a lot more amusing. Instead of that single irritating Radio DJ with the same 6 voice clips El Presidente‎ pretty much shares his palace with his aides and faction heads who bring a new feature to the Tropico table with missions that appease your government, the factions or just a slightly easier way to help fill your bank balance or satisfy your people to some extent. And it isn't just your guys the faceless super powers from the first game have been given faces AND both the EU, China and the Middle East have joined in to squabble for your tiny Islands precious resources. This is a pretty good thing as it also gives you a reason to actually play the Main Campaign that has been tweaked a lot around these new additions. They also make sandbox games a slightly less tedious treck.There is of course the mandatory couple of new buildings of every type and a couple of new outfits to dress up your Corrupt Carribean Dictator too. And yeah sadly that is it. Of course there is also the suspicious hefty amount of DLC packs with a lot of additional content that should really have been in the game. This game really is more Tropico: The Directors Cut The Electric Phantom Part II than Tropico 4. But hey, they added Twitter with the Facebook Social functions and new achivements if that is your thing!I sort of wish they made the effort and a DLC that added some new Islands or Music as around the 20 hour mark like with a decent old movie you love to break out every few months to comfort yourself you eventually notice the limited flaws.So yeah, final word. Pick it up with all the DLC during a sale if you are a big Tropico/Management game fan or want to try something new.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Build your tropical island paradise, or build a fascist dictatorship of tyrrany and oppression. In Tropico 4, you are the dictator of a small Caribbean island. Grow your nation, become an economical powerhouse, a military powerhouse, or a vacation paradise. One major upside to this game is that it has a lot more decoration buildings and items and isn't as strict about buildings needing to be placed near a road, like Tropico 5. So grab your guns and fight for tyranny and oppression, or against it!Viva Tropico! Viva El Presidente!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												As someone who adores Tropico 3, I felt skeptical about playing this game, since most of the assets are ripped straight from its predescessor, and the mechanics are very similar, although distinctly improved.What I discovered when I finally got around to playing it, however, is a beautifully silly game. Where Tropico 3 had tossed out puns and occasional tongue-in-cheek exclamations over the radio, Tropico 4 has mostly-voiced campaigns, a suite of comedic characters with hilarious interactions, a genuinely funny radio announcement for a lot of the buildings (which does not play as frustratingly frequently as in 3), and a distinct sense of absurdity in the very structure of the campaign. For instance, one of the campaign missions has a series of voice clips which are direct spoofs of "the most interesting man in the world," which left me giggling to myself.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												Haemimont and Kalypso really struck gold with this one. Re-labelling Tropico 3 and marketing it as a new game was really brilliant. I'm very glad I had the opportunity to pay for another copy of Tropico 3, since I enjoyed it so much. I also enjoyed paying for the nickel-and-dime DLC that adds a pitiful amount of buildings that took all of five minutes to cobble together in Haemimont's modeling software. This is really the most pathetic cash grab gaming has ever seen.♥♥♥♥ you Kalypso.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I felt from the very beginning I played this game this one was good. However other people don't think that way:  ''I don't like it. Its a rubish game''- Said me a friend.I like it but that doesn't mean you will like it. I enjoy it 'cause I play  meanwhile i'm watching a film or speaking with friends by any software or doing whatever. That's because this game is a bit slow. For example, you need X $ to build something. If you don't have that money you won't build it and that's why you must wait and since waiting isn't funny doing another thing wil keep you enjoyed the time you are waiting. Apart from that problem I can't say anything more bad about this gem. ITs a really funny game with lot of action and interesting things. All levels are difficult and you must thing whats the best way to be rich in all of them. So coming again to the question if I'd recommend it: I will to those people who likes doing 2 things at once and to those who like calm games of building a city. And well, i wouldn't pay more than 5€ for this, maybe 10€ if you really want it. If it helped you like it! :P Thanks and have a good day!

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I felt from the very beginning I played this game this one was good. However other people don't think that way:  ''I don't like it. Its a rubish game''- Said me a friend.I like it but that doesn't mean you will like it. I enjoy it 'cause I play  meanwhile i'm watching a film or speaking with friends by any software or doing whatever. That's because this game is a bit slow. For example, you need X $ to build something. If you don't have that money you won't build it and that's why you must wait and since waiting isn't funny doing another thing wil keep you enjoyed the time you are waiting. Apart from that problem I can't say anything more bad about this gem. ITs a really funny game with lot of action and interesting things. All levels are difficult and you must thing whats the best way to be rich in all of them. So coming again to the question if I'd recommend it: I will to those people who likes doing 2 things at once and to those who like calm games of building a city. And well, i wouldn't pay more than 5€ for this, maybe 10€ if you really want it. If it helped you like it! :P Thanks and have a good day!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Excellent economics, politics, logistics and overall city building simulation featuring very nicely done funny and overly stereotypical characters.It is true that the basic Tropico 4 is just an improved Tropico 3 which even uses the same engine and mostly the same graphical assets. But the additions are improvements in my oppinion and the things added later with the Modern Times DLC make the game very different from its predecessor. I wouldn't recommend any of the other DLCs unless you buy a whole bundle because the one mission and one building they each provide are barely worth one €uro and most of the added buildings are unbalanced in a way so they just make the game a less difficult.The simulation is very detailed, so you can actually follow every single person on your island on their daily routes through your cities. Finding out about their needs and their thoughts is actually possible. But most of the times I didn't invest too much time into that and focussed on macro-mechanics. Managing to keep your standings on sane levels with both your factions and foreign powers while at the same time doing what is needed to win the mission can be a hard job sometimes.After a long time of playing and optimizing my strategies, the worst thing I found in the game is a point in each round, where the tension is finally removed because the economy is working well, money is flowing in and the people just love you. There was barely ever a game in which there appeared any new difficulty after that point. If you just consider this situation a win it all becomes less of a problem.Another slightly flawed concept seems to be the money in the swiss bank account you can gather through different ways. It makes you have less money available to spend on infrastructure and does not have any other use than improving your game's score. In a future Tropico I hope there is some further use to that. Mechanically sometimes the street building through rocky areas is a bit annoying because you cannot remove the rocks and sometimes need to remove pieces of streets again because there is no angle available anymore to attach a further piece.Also a very unneccessary annoyance is the additional Kalypso account you need to register to access the game. One would think that the need to have a logged in Steam account would be enough to verify that you own the game. I hope for their next game they realize that annoying their legal customers is not a good way to counter piracy.Overall the game gave me more than 120 hours of much appreciated gameplay. I damn well recommend buying this, especially as a complete bundle on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Put into the role of a leader of a tropical nation, you will find yourself deciding to provide fair treatment to your people or to rule them with an iron fist.You spend your money (and tax dollars from your people) on things that will make your city better. Whether you choose to cater to your people with local jobs and exports or outsource and try to bring in tourism, it's all up to you.There are options for corruption too. You can get protesters "removed" or run fraudulent banks that will skim off parts of the money for your private off-shore bank account.The choice is yours, but the worse you treat your people the more likely it is you will get assassinated and the game is over.81/100

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												This game as a city builder and government simulation game is a perfect mixture of genres. You build and industrialize a small island in the Caribbean during the cold war times throughout the game the USSR and USA are constantly fighting for your favor a perfect example of the small conflicts of the cold war that don't get too much attention. The characters that appear to you in the game are all very well done caricatures of their home nation or political alignment and are good for a quick laugh when they bring up the issues of the island to you. The game is complex enough for a veteran of these type of games to enjoy it and simple enough for newcomers to have fun too. You can choose from many ways to rule your country, a democracy, a dictatorship, nationalist, communist. the diversity makes this game feel to have no limits and infinite possibilities. I give this game a 9/10 if you want to get into city builder games or civilization type games this is a good stepping stone.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 31
												tl;dr: Tropico 4 has a pretty large fanbase and a very distinct, very enjoyable style to it. Its more of a feeling than a game, and albeit being very fun it becomes old quickly, further down in this review I will elaborate on this. I dont think it is worth 14,99€ just for that, so definately do wait for a sale before picking this up if you wanna be cautious. That being said of the 60 hours I spent right now on this game I consider at least 30 hours well spent. The reason my review is a downvote is solely to give contrast and a critical view for people that just dont know.And just for reference here: I played Tropico 2 and Tropico 5 too, the core mechanics of the games do not change very much and most people like 4 over 5, so keep that in mind before making any decisions. Lets get to the game.Tropico 4 looks and feels like one big slightly politicized Advertisement for Vacation in Cuba back in the Days. This is not a bad thing. In fact this is propably the most important part of what makes this game so good in the eyes of many, and it held up for most of my playtime. If you are looking for a casual, fun game Tropico 4 cannot possibly dissappoint you. The Devs understood really well what makes this games experience so enjoyable on the surface and crafted just enough details and then alot of DLC's to hold up with that feeling.Sometimes the visuals look a little weird in terms of colors, because everything is so bright and colorful yet at the same time the buildings are so dull. In some instances it makes the game look slightly bad, especially when zoomed out, but its the smallest of problems really. The soundtrack is amazing, as are the general designs of menus et cetera.The game is a joy to see when you zoom in, and I would suggest that you do exactly that for most of the time. Observe, Decorate, build your private dictatorship island. Assassinate people and build roach patrol apartments for the poor. Import  Uranium and build big power plants and nuclear warheads. Do not play this like a strategy game, play this like a story/experience.To get why im saying this I must first give you a glimpse of how the mechanics in the game work. People live in shacks, people really only need 2 things to stay alive for long, those are food and healthcare. Also, people will arrive with immigration, so they are expendable. All of them are simulated on their own, you actually have as many people as the numbers say on the island. If they want to get to work, or want to satisfy any need, the people will leave their place and go to the spot where they can do that. Either they venture to a garage and get a car or they walk. Buildings that are connected to streets automatically supply the people with cars, cars VANISH on the end of one way. This means if you have a farm, people can drive TO the farm, but not AWAY from the farm. Also, you will get at least 500 people in some city after a certain amount of time. All of those people will drive a car if you supply them with one. Walking takes a ♥♥♥♥♥on of time, so its a good idea to build garages literally on every other corner.This is where the biggest problems of the game all stem from.Firstoff, you have NO direct control over traffic other than building roads and garages. All the roads will be single lane two way roads. You wont often find a midgame where you dont start seeing traffic problems. That goes especially for the goods being transported by truck drivers in literally any building that produces goods. The best advise I can give is to make long transport routes around the cities without many intersections for the goods (you need to be careful that those routes are the quickest though, otherwise the AI wont choose them) and hope for the best, you cant avoid traffic problems as a whole. Dealing with all of this makes the economy game incredibly frustrating. Especially because you also dont have control of what goods are being transported first, and therefore its very common to see income fluctiations.Luckily, this doesnt matter."But how can it not matter?"Because the game is quite possibly the easiest strategy game known to mankind. I never failed and boy did I initially fail hard in some missions. Its really hard to completely get to game over, and its in my eyes impossible to build an entirely failing economy. Your island could have no ressources at all and you can still pull it off by importing and manifacturing.If you desperately need money, just build 2 Jewelry Factories, set gold imports on, set the import slider to unlimited, after a few months they will pay for themselves and after that you're gonna swim in cash. Same goes for Weapons. Same goes for Oil Products. Same goes for Furniture, to be honest same goes for everything more or less.Tourism is a nice steady income and forces you to actually pay attention to how you build things, but its infinitely worse than industry in every way. (Still a fun thing you should try out.)So the economy is not a challenge, what about the politics, do they matter?Yes, the policies you can enact can matter, and thats one of the strongest suits of the game. Often they are just nobrainers to either do or not do, but you actually can manipulate the game and the challenges you bring to yourself so that it feels >slightly< different everytime. Thats the most you can do.I played one Island completely communist, one Island completely capitalist, one Island focused on a Military dictatorship without builing any houses for the general population, just food and healthcare.And what were the biggest differences?In the Military dictatorship more people protested. Sometimes I got a rebel attack.The people also had more time to work. Thats about it. On Average I maybe had 40% Happyness (given a rich militaristic/intellectual upper class), thats 30% lower from my happiest island. Its almost like they dont care.And that while having no Liberty enhancing buildings or anything else, just food and healthcare. If you spend more than 30 hours you will quickly start to think that every island feels like the same, this is very obnoxious to notice if you play through the campaign. The only saving grace MIGHT be the DLC's or you as player going for some self sought vision.Which can always be fun, but in the end, no matter what you do, all your decisions feel like cosmetic overlay over the same broken♥♥♥♥♥island. Again, and again, and again.Thats the game.Theres nothing you could quickly change in the game to fix this entirely, and thats where all the DLC's come from.Your main objective hence should be to build a pretty island and fool around. Can you do that?A little bit, yes. The first island will look really good to you if you give it some patience and care, manually design districts and make everything look good with decorations. Then you go to the second island and guess what? It looks the same.The biggest differences always come through the islands themselves, but if they dont matter economically, and if they dont matter politically, how much of a game do I truly have?I honestly believe this is still a good buy for casual gamers, I honestly believe that you will have alot of fun on your first two or three islands and I honestly believe if you add the DLC it has decent numbers of content to play around with, but is it a good game?My Answer has to be no..And thats sad for me, since I love the series so much that I even listen to the soundtrack in my free time.But its just not a good strategy game, or even a good game. Its a polished but very confused sandbox dictatorship island that over long enough playtime eventually dissolves into a vast nothingness of senseless routine.And for that reason, I just cannot recommend it even though I love the series. I hope they can seriously improve the gameplay for the next one, because 5 didnt add or fix that much either afaik.(And sorry, but disasters are a complete joke. The game wouldve been better without them.)

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
												I bought Tropico 4 as part of a bundle however despite many attempts and a number of wasted hours have never made it past the 3rd party DRM registration. As a last gasp attempt to get it sorted I have gone directly to their web page and reset two of my email accounts, which were apparentely created by the launcher, even tthough the launcher just whirls away and gives no response. I also created a third email account directly on their web page. However none of this resolved as the emails have never been received (before you ask, I have checked my spam folder).I am pretty tech savvy, working in the industry anyway and have never seen such a poor registration implementation and I include some of the bigger companies in that list as they can often be pretty poor as well. When you are unable to bypass the registration to play a game then you know you are facing an uphill struggle.So in summary I would rate Tropico 4 0/10 as I can't play it and can't bypass the registration (without implementing some hacks, which I refuse to do).The developer response was also pretty poor and never went beyond one question about the issue, which I had already answered in my original post (it would be nice if they actually read it before responding) and one statement to highlight the fact they state the game requires 3rd party DRM registration - I know that, that's why I am posting in their fourms asking for help with the registration!I have read quite a few similar stories in forums, etc.So a big thumbs down from me.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												This game is like sim city but better. In Sim City you have to set up water systems for your people and make sure they thrive as a city and more b******t, whereas in this game you can let and your d******d citizens starve and then get invaded by the USSR. It's made by some studios that I have never heard of but it doesn't matter as their servers are still quicker than EA's. Also, it is a very mature game as it has racial stereotypes such as accents of the Chinese and getting awarded by the Middle East with camels. Its dialogue isn't cheesy, boring and s**t like other city simulators but actually says how we think it. The bakground music actually makes you feel happy eventhough you know that you are living in your parent's house basement, have no friends and cannot talk to girls without taking a dose of Xanex and pretending to be drunk but you only get drunk off of 2 sips of water.If you are procrastinating and cannot be bothered doing revision for your upcoming GCSE's, like taking long walks on the beach and/or have a large♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ this game is where to go.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
Product received for free
												In a world of shady devs that sit down and figure out how to milk the most money or privacy invasion out of their customers, and then have their marketing team make it sound like they're doing you a favor, it's so refreshing to see a game like Tropico 4 call attention in its features list to their facebook integration. I can't wait to litter my facebook with updates on my progress in the game, and I guess the game will get free advertisement from that too, so it's really a win-win.I was already excited when I saw how the devs had kindly programmed the game to post to my social media, but when I booted the game and saw that I had to register an email address with them just to play this single-player game, I was overjoyed. I wouldn't want to accidentally start playing without receiving the "free benefit of game news & updates" in my email inbox, of course! If a paid DLC came out without my knowledge, I'd be heartbroken.Thank you, Kalypso Games, for this masterpiece of consumer-focused design. I bet you sleep real easy at night, knowing that everything you did was for your players and not pure greed so thinly disguised as a feature as to be blatantly insulting to our intelligence.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Have played each game in the Tropico series and would have to give this game a 9.2/10.Excellent small city building game based in the Caribbean, where you are a dictator and manage everything from your citizens everyday lives to a thriving industry based under both tourism with basic resource gathering and factory production to really roll out the profit. There is also considerble detail put into the game's detail and mechanics.The only real drawbacks I've found are your citizens are quite lazy so one must carefully plan out there city, less they begin running into traffic problems or workers not arriving at their jobs quickly enough.The "Modern Times" dlc addresses such an issue with subway systems, which as another note, the dlc truly enchances this game to an amazing and well balanced gameplay.

Product received for free
												This game is pretty Awesome, You get to choose an island that you will fully control, There are many leaders to choose from, Including The Infamous Fidel Castro, And the charsmatic Che Guevara, You have to balance every single aspect of your citizen's life, if poverty increases then there's a high chance of less voting for you, or sometimes a military coup, So be careful, Also it's fun playing with cheats, You get to interact with other major super powers like The USSR, The USA, The middle east (Although it's not technically a superpower) and other countries, There's a chance The US might invade you, and annex your island (Imperialists much?), I give this game a 9/10, Solid game, Had some bugs with it not gonna lie, everything else is solid as rock.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												The Tropico series is probably my favorite of the genre, and that's saying a lot.  It takes a while to get acclimated to the rules of running your own island (how rent/wages work, etc.), but is a lot of fun once you get a handle on what you're doing.  The campaign is fairly lengthy though I'm not a fan of the timed quests you'll enconter from time to tim.  Luckily, there's a sandbox mode that eliminates the pressures of the campaign.  Whether it be exports or tourism, your main goal is to keep your bank full whilst keeping your Tropicans happy.  Tropico 3 is almost identical in playstyle, so pick that up for cheaper to see if this is something you'd enjoy.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Much like a Caribbean vacation, you might not want to come home. The atmosphere above anything else really sells this game. The tropical feel and island music spices up what could be another city builder clone. In addition the sense of humor and satire prevalent throughout the game gives levity to what usually could be the typical boring "Please build X" communication from advisors. The campaign offers several different scenarios with a moderately engaging overarching story. However, by the last few missions, the typical routine of "establish industry, save enough money, complete objectives", starts to get tedious. In addition, the AI pathing can lead to some frustration in waiting endlessly for a structure to be constructed or a resource to be delivered. Despite this though, the game gets a recommendation for city builder fans who are looking for a more tropical change of scenery.

This is improved with the DLC, but most missions can be solved in a similar way with a little bit of consideration of the random or not so random events.Recommend if you like Tropico 3.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												This game is fun to learn, by all means! It's an attractive, well-themed, humorously tongue-in-cheek city sim. The radio personalities, the music, and the graphics all contribute to an entertaining experience that will keep you riveted for easily ten maps.However, once you've got the basics down - about 15 missions into the campaign, if you've bothered - there's really no reward for you to keep playing. Every island follows the exact same pattern, every playthrough is identical. The campaign missions themselves are really pathetic, with a lame plot for each mission stretched over way too many pointless and time-wasting checkpoints. The auto-generated faction and foreign power tasks are predictable and lame as well, and utterly ignorable most of the time.The biggest challenge in the game comes from street planning - no joke. By the time your economy has matured, the layout of roads on your island is the only thing that can shut you down. If you have too many intersections, say goodbye to ever turning an export profit ever again. No one seems to be sure if these traffic management problems were entirely intentional, or an idea that snowballed into a monstrosity. I'm told the Modern Times expansion's "Metro" building helps with this, but truly, why bother?Tropico 4 offers no reward for mastery or sustained interest, but can offer about 20 hours worth of good clean fun. It's worth picking up on sale if nowhere else, but I'd steer clear of the DLC; save yourself a few bucks.

Product received for free
												This game is pretty Awesome, You get to choose an island that you will fully control, There are many leaders to choose from, Including The Infamous Fidel Castro, And the charsmatic Che Guevara, You have to balance every single aspect of your citizen's life, if poverty increases then there's a high chance of less voting for you, or sometimes a military coup, So be careful, Also it's fun playing with cheats, You get to interact with other major super powers like The USSR, The USA, The middle east (Although it's not technically a superpower) and other countries, There's a chance The US might invade you, and annex your island (Imperialists much?), I give this game a 9/10, Solid game, Had some bugs with it not gonna lie, everything else is solid as rock.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
Product received for free
												I received Tropico 4 for free from a Humble Bundle promotion.Tropico 4 is a city building game, a genre not usually my forte, but it's similar to other ones that I've played like Simcity and the Anno (Year #) series. You decide what buildings to make, and your people will semi-automatically fill their roles to become your laborers, craftsmen, police officers, priests, and whatever else you need on your Caribbean island during the Cold War years (1960 onward).Once you get the hang of things, you may begin to find that building a city from the ground up is extremely easy. Your people will demand certain amenities, but these demands are given to you on an almanac you may access at any time. Are people homeless? Build some apartments. Is a demand for healthcare, religion, or entertainment being unmet? Put down a clinic, church, or cabaret, and the problem will solve itself in time. If all needs are met, it's time to make some money with exports or tourism.Throughout the 20-mission campaign (in which you almost always start with the same set of basic buildings and end up populating a small fraction of the island), you are presented with different obstacles... but you can build your city nearly the exact same way every time. One island supposedly has a crime problem, but you'll only need to put down a police station earlier than you otherwise might. One island has a rebel problem, so you'll need more military buildings earlier. The problems are thrown at you one island at a time, and only a small tweak is needed to keep things running smoothly.Despite the wide variety of buildings, many of them either have little or identical effects. Farms growing cash crops, mines, industries, and tourism all make you money behind the scenes. All you need to do is analyze what your available assets are, and place buildings for the one that'll get the most return on investment. Your citizens handle the nitty-gritty of transporting and exporting the goods.There's a wide swath of entertainment buildings, but unless you are going for tourism or trying to build a giant, deliriously happy island, most of them are not useful. Cabarets provide good entertainment for all Tropican citizens, and don't require electricity. Unless you are swimming in money (and you will be after a while), there's no need for pubs, restaurants, casinos, or roller coasters.Your island has different factions like Communists or Capitalists whom you must please if you want them to vote for you in the periodic elections, but it's fairly easy to keep all of them happy. Even if you are in danger of losing an election, there are many ways to steal it at the last second, like signing edicts that people like, upping everyone's pay, bribing faction leaders, or just rigging the election. The same goes for foreign powers. In all my time playing so far, I've gotten China annoyed enough to embargo me once. That's all.I'm going to say that I don't recommend this game, but with the stipulation that if you like city building games with an easygoing pace and low level of difficulty, you may like this anyway. If you're new to city building games or gaming in general, it might be a good starting point before tackling something less forgiving. But if you're looking for a challenge, look elsewhere.

												Ok. So maybe in Tropico my priorities were a bit one sided and may have caused a small uprising. But so what? That's the absolute glory of this amazing city builder. content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
Surprisingly, it's a really rather good city-builder*disclaimer, long and detailed review, skip to bottom for final verdictI got Tropico 4 in a humble bundle, kind've only wanting the other games in the bundle. So there it sat in my vast Steam library, not really doing anything. And then, my friend told me about a really good city-builder that he had been playing. I thought, "oh Simcity, right?" Wrong. He was talking about Tropico, (Tropico 5 however). At this time, I had forgotten that I even had it. So, when I looked it up on the steam store, I realised that I already had it. So, I gave it a shot. And I was quite presently surprised! So, here is a list explaining the good and bad elements of Tropico 4 and there reasons.Pros+Each little person has their own profile;What was one of the elements that made Tropico stand out was the ability to click on every little person walking around, doing there daily routine. Once you clicked on them, a profile of the character came up, explaining their age, wellbeing, faction, name, where they work and where they live. It would also make the camera follow that person. Sometimes, I would find myself just seeing people go about their daily lives for hours on end.+In the population, there are structured families;A little more of a unnecessary part of the game, (but undoubtedly cool) was the structured families. Sometimes when checking people's profiles, you may find a group of people with the same last name. At first, I thought ths was just due to the developers not putting enough names in. But then, I executed a guy, and then everybody with the same last name as him got enraged. Confused, I looked at the effects of executing someone, and it said; "victim's family will become enraged" and thats when I realised, there was families, which is really cool!+A system where technology evolves with time;Much like Civilization V (which is an utterly fantastic strategy game), technology would advance as time goes on. This means, that I might start out with some crappy tenements, but when I research more stuff, I could have super high-tec shopping malls. Nuff said.+The ability of extreme POWER;In this game, you have the power of anything and everything on the island, (apart from the rebels, which we will get to later). None of the decisions will be made for you, you have to make them. There are recomendations for what to build, but I mostly found myself ignoring them, as sometimes they can screw you over.+Rebels;The rebels system in this game is rather good. It's simple, when someone becomes too unhappy with the island, they will become a rebel. Rebels can and will screw you over. They will start fires, attack buildings and people and generally become out of control.+Disasters;Perhaps copying other citybuilders, this game has disasters. Dont worry though, you won't be having meteors or aliens or...dinosaurs *cough*Simcity*cough*. Just normal things like nuclear bombs or volcano eruptions or earthquakes. And it won't just be mildly annoying either, it will seriously screw you over. Once, when I built my city next to a volcano, thinking it would look pretty cool, lets just say it wasn't cool when flying blobs of lava engulfed the city and I went financialy in debt.So, thats the list of things which I think are pretty cool in this game. Now, we will talk about the cons.Cons-Limited time;The thing I can think of straight off the bat is that it has a limited amount of time for a game, even in sandbox mode! Sure it is a while, but one time, I built a really great city...and then I couldn't play anymore because my "mandate had run out", and that was on maximum time. Sure, it adds realism, but sometimes fun should overweigh how realistic it is. This is where Just Cause 2 shined, now you might be thinking, "what the devil, what on Earth has that got ot do with Tropico?!" well, my friend; nothing. I was just bringing it up. Anyways, the reason Just Cause 2 was so fun is that it was completely unrealistic. Tropico should get some inspiration off that.-Lack of help;One of the annoying things about this game is that it just throws you in with "build a city". This is a large downside, as the game is quite complicated in the financial part of things. Alot of the time, I found myself looking at my amount of money, going down by the thousands, completely confused why.-Graphics;Now, I would like to point out that this is a very small and minor problem, especially considering it's a citybuilder. But the graphics are a little lacking.Final VerdictSo, we are down to the final verdict, and, if you couldn't already tell with the big blue thumbs up stamped on, I most certainly recomend Tropico 4! Even though it has flaws, I can still say this is a great, solid citybuilder. Thank you for taking some time to read this!

content:
Posted: February 24, 2013
												Pretty interesting, more so than one of the Sim City's I played at the very least. Want to build your own little Communist paradise, an oppresssive militarist government, or a joyful little hub of capitalism & consumerism; it's all there.There are also a small host of sterotypical characters which represent every faction/interest group. Besides constantly wanting to decapitate Sunny Flowers, the enviromental activist, they're all either tolerable or interesting.And I do have a pretty good time gunning down religious rebels every now & then who are angry since I won't build churches or have stupid bans on things like contraception. I also quite enjoy tossing devoutly religious and capitalist people into my labor camps. :DLong live El Presidente, Comrade Winston!

content:
Posted: April 18
												Tropico is a city building game along the lines of Simcity.  Although a great deal of attention has been paid to creating depth for the game, it suffers from one huge deficit that limits long term playability.  It lacks a way to flatten (or alter) terrain, leaving the most interesting parts of the map unusable.  Really, what's the point of building a huge statue if you can't place it at the top of a cliff, or up on the side of a mountain where everyone can see it?  On one Kalypso forum,  they claimed that this 'feature' was included by design to make the game more challenging.  If so, this was a bad decision.  This same approach to terrain makes road placement difficult and imprecise.  Bottom line : maybe they fixed this in version 5, but I'm not spending the money to find out.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2012
												Tropico 4 is definitely a game to pick up if you like management of cities and a whole banana republic island. You are El Presidente and your people need you to lead them into prosperity... or annilation. If you haven't played any of the Tropico games I suggest this over Tropico 3. But if you have already played Tropico 3, you shouldn't really need to worry about this, it feels more like this should have been an expansion or a patch for Tropico 3. Having said that, it's not a bad game in the least. Sim City fans will enjoy it, but maybe not hardcore fans as you aren't zoning your residential and industry areas but it's certainly nothing like Sim City Societies, and you aren't managing populations of thousands, you are managing hundreds of individuals of whom you can watch their daily routine, and you can hire and fire those individual people. Tropico 4 is a great simulation game. 9/10

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												If you like heavily scenario-based sim city type games then this is a good one. Keep in mind though that this game differs from things like sim city not only in the heavy emphasis on scenario objectives, but also you're in a command economy dictatorship. You don't simply "zone" a residential area, you command your peon followers to build an apartment building exactly where you want it, and if they don't like that then they're perfectly free to get shot in the head for their traitorous discontent.One of the great things about this game is the political system which allows you to give speeches that pay lipservice to various things while taking absolutely no actions to further them. For example, praise the spirit of communism while you do exactly the opposite of what the communist faction wants.... it'll still keep them happier for longer than if you didn't. Got annoying peolpe voting against you? Just have them shot or get into an "accident", though these kinds of operations will cost you money.Before you buy Tropico 5, I'd recommend getting Tropico 4 on sale to try it out.Only real problem with the game, and its more of an annoyance than anyting, is the extra DRM: they make you create an account on the publisher's servers just to launch the game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
Product received for free
												Picked this game up for free expecting it to be pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Installed it after having it sit in my library for a few months and booted it up.  Gameplay 	The gameplay is simple but some things can be confusing unless you do the tutorials.  (Though if you've played city management games it probably won't be too hard).  There's not alot of customization to the buildings and alot are copy/past  with only a few providing alternate models.  The maps are also very uneven and unless there's some world editor I'm missing, a good portion of the map is virtually unusable. With the maps becoming pretty small and after a few hours of playing, the majority of usable space will be taken up.  Some maps don't even have all of the mining resources and thus some foreign deals are unable to be done.    This game is also stupidly easy, I usually suck at city builders yet I was raking in money with everyone in the world and all of my citizens all perfectly happy with me.  Any conflicts or disasters are stupidly easy to overcome and provide no challenge at all.  Once had a tornado run straight through the thickest part of my city and I lost a farm, garage, and church, which took around 3 seconds to fix.  Money can start off slow but eventually if you just spam out farms w/ tobacco and then cigar plants and make 300k per export.  There's variety with paths you can take your goverment but I don't feel as if this gives it along playtime.  Speaking of the playtime the game is really fun at first but quickly gets old and boring.  Going down different government choices can lead to different experiences but those will get old soon along with your original playthrough.   Campaign	The campaign takes 30mins to complete with you just having to win the election through various means.  Even though I was in debt, hated by commies, ecos, religious, and loyalists, I still won majority vote without ANY manipulation of the election.  You can continue the story after that but it's just a repeat. Sound	Voice acting is a bit dull (and racial/politcal stereotyped really hard) but at least the music is kickass.  I could listen to the relaxing music for hours and it really compliments the mood that the game is trying to have.   Graphics	Graphics look pretty nice for being a bit old and enjoyable. Overall This game is fairly simple and lacking of too much content but it's worth a few hours of your time if the price is on sale.  It's a nice game to relax with and enjoy.  Wouldn't recommend to people that play alot of city builders due to the oversimplistic and easier mechanics compared to other games in the genre such as Skylines.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Pros:- Excellent humor/satire. If you like overexaggerated. stereotype humor- or Junot Diaz - this is for you. - Cohesive art direction. (As opposed to, say, T5)- Easy enough that you don't have to micro-manage. Important because I can never built a fully functional city in Sim City, but I've done it 32 times here.- Multiple ways to earn cash, the grease of dictatorship.- Interesting campaign storyline + mission limitations. - Plenty of diabolical dictator things to do - built a city full of crime and exploit the criminals in labor camps. It's not gonna get much into your Swiss Bank Account, but BOY is it fun.Cons:- Every stage you restart building a mostly empty island for the main campaigns. Super repetitive.- Once you know how the game works, the campaigns can be unchallenging.- It's got nothing to offer for someone looking for a detailed city builder. - There's only really one 'true' way to play the game - build a paradise island with an amazing economy and keep everyone happy. Sure, you can build a giant army and keep everyone in prison and labor camps like a true dictator - but since all the missions and goals ends with people being happy, at the end of the day you'll still revert to the default island angelico gameplay. That's not to say it isn't fun to try though...Side note:Get the Modern Times DLC, if nothing else. The voice acting and the campaign is weaker than the main game, but it adds a lot to the game if you already like it.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												To say that I became lightly obsessed with Tropico 4 is an understatement. It does offer massive improvements over the previous releases in the franchise, and it does offer all kinds of various play modes and routes you can take. As a city builder, it's one of the most fun games I've ever played. It is a time sink, it does suck up many hours of your life that you'll never get back. However, you're having fun the whole time so it's not a waste of that time, either. I've nearly finished the main campaign, and I've obviously played a good bit of the other options to rack up my game time as it is, and I don't really have any plans of stopping until I play as much of the game as possible. It's fun, sarcastic, satirical, critical, all the things you would expect from something as tongue-in-cheek as the series presents itself. You are guaranteed to have fun if you're a fan of the genre. However, Tropico 4 is not free of issues, and denying the glaring issues would make me a fan to an uncomfortable level. Even for the time it was released, the visuals aren't that great. Then again, with this type of game, the visuals aren't exactly why you're playing. The character designs are quite funny, the dialog and accents are giggle-worthy, and the jokes do get a little bit much after awhile. The largest problem I have with it is the natural disasters. After awhile, they start to lag horribly, in particular, in my case, the oil tanker spills tend to lock up the game and will often unfreeze the game themselves after a somewhat extended period of time (1-2 minutes), or I will have to completely close the game and start whatever campaign mission I'm on over altogether. Even with this issue, it's done little to detract from my enjoyment of it. Another somewhat negative aspect of the game is the soundtrack. It's great for awhile, but after that while, it tends to grate on your nerves a good bit because it's the same 3-4 songs played over and over. It's not that I expected them to have an entirely fresh soundtrack for the game, but a little more variety would've been nice. Luckily you can turn the music off and put your own on in the background and that will take care of that minor complaint. The good parts are many, and again, you WILL enjoy yourself if you enjoy city builders. Ultimately, all the decisions are left up to you, but as the campaign itself progresses, you will have more challenging obstacles to overcome (as is expected.) My suggestion would be to get this on sale, but not to overlook it. For what it is, it's great, and I've spent a lot of time trying to figure out how to be a well-liked and strong dictator. Now I want to buy my own island. Overall, 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												I quite enjoyed the game at first, but cannot recommend it due to the lack of content and how easy it is.Once you have built one mega island with every building on it, the only thing that changes about new islands is handicaps and mission events; the game was just too simple for me to enjoy like I enjoy most economy management games.It's a shame, because the game does do some interesting things with the political side of running a city which other games shy away from, and the artwork for the characters is amazing.It also has some features which may be leftovers from previous games or something, in that you can select people in your game individually and see info on them as well as various options (mostly involving kidnapping or killing them) similar to dwarf fortress.I never one needed to actually use this system as, other than mission NPC's, all my people loved me too much.I completed most of the story missions and tried out some free form games, all my cities quickly reached 80% happyness in all catagories, and my money was always in the hundred thousands. It wasn't particularly challenging once I could afford to quickbuild (it's a button the instantly builds a structure for cash without waiting for a building crew, which shouldn't be in the game IMO) any buildings I wanted and I never once lost an island.All in all, it's a neat little game that lacks any real challenge and isn't quite deep enough on the economy side to keep me interested past the first few islands.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												Tropico has had so many installments and seperate DLC that the whole series has become a joke.Tropico 4 is better than Tropico 5 in my opinion, because it's more focused in it's original goal.  Tropico by nature isn't supposed to be a city builder, it's supposed to be a Political game, in other words it's a game where you literally make your own nation.  T4 gives you much more control and fine tuning to do these things.Sure, T5 looks better, and it's easier to place buildings in perfect placement,  but it fails at it's core concept.I don't explicitly reccomend either game, but if I had to reccomend one, it'd be T4.  It's cheaper, it's more true to the core concept of the series, and it doesn't have an astronomical amount of terrible nickle and diming DLC tacked onto it like T5 does.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												I decided to revisit Tropico in the form of Tropico 4. I played the original as a kid, and skipped Tropico 2 and 3. Ultimately, Tropico 4 seemed promising at first, but I quickly reached a certain point where it started to feel repetitive and too easy. I guess the crux of it is that if you plan your first steps correctly, you can make your profits grow exponentially such that by late game you have more money than you know what to do with. That means that by the the time you progress to a more developed island, the gameplay has gotten pretty boring. A lot of the main story games involve large sum payments, which just feels like a waiting game. Based on my experience, it has no replay value for me and I don't see myself playing this version again. I wish they had added a few more key aspects to the game rather than just updating the art, engine, and adding some more buildings. But it isn't completely terrible, so while I'm not recommending it, I'm not condemning it either. If you find it on sale for a few dollars, it might be worth giving it a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												The only Tropico I've had the pleasure to play, This is a simple city builder; you don't need to manage detailed finances like the old Sim Citys, or zone sections off of the land or deal much with traffic. Just simply pick a building, find a spot, and plunk it down. The meat and potatos is in the export based economy. Find resources to utilize, and "design" an efficient economy that keeps goods moving from the initial point, to the docks and out of the country. Important to a lesser extent are the tourism and service industries. Look for a nice part of the Island, and turn it into a kitschy tourist district. You can have them mingle with local Tropicans, or keep them away. Other things to deal with: keeping the various factions happy, and keeping the foreign powers happy. Set in the 1960s, it behooves you to keep the US and USSR content in relations. Otherwise an implied invasion force ends the game. You can also lose the game by losing elections. Keep the people happy, and they'll vote for you. You can be Presidente for life. That is of course if you allow elections in the first place.There's lots of humor to this, and it doesn't take itself seriously. The soundtrack is great, especially if you've listened to the Salsa and Merengue. The graphics and art is beautiful, yet it can look like a slum if you want/cause it to. In the end, this game is perfect if you want to get your city building fix in, it doesn't require much time, and the learning curve is simple.Penultimo beckons.

												Wouldn't know what the game plays like. I know you're forced to sign up for solicitation emails with having to create an account to play the game. I also know that it doesn't support "ALT+Enter" to switch to and from windowed mode, so if you want to run windowed mode, you get the lowest resolution possible. I switch the game to run in 4k, so it at least matches my main monitor, and it just crashes when I try to start a game. It doesn't matter which mode I choose. Then I get the joy of all the settings reverting back to the minimum specs because it *must* be that my SLI GTX 980 gaming rig in incapable of handling those settings in a 4 year old game. Bad Rats was a better game, because at least it was playable.

    Poet's Page    Poems    Comments    Stats    Biography    Quotations    Share on Facebook    Share on TwitterPoems by Kingsley Amis : 4 / 6    « The Voice of Authority: A Lang    Untitled »To A Baby Born Without LimbsThis is just to show you whose boss around here.It’ll keep you on your toes, so to speak,Make you put your best foot forward, so to speak,And give you something to turn your hand to, so to speak.You can face up to it like a man,Or snivvle and blubber like a baby.That’s up to you. Nothing to do with Me.If you take it in the right spirit,You can have a bloody marvelous life,With the great rewards courage brings,And the beauty of accepting your LOT.And think how much good it’ll do your Mum and Dad,And your Grans and Gramps and the rest of the shower,To be stopped being complacent.Make sure they baptise you, though,In case some murdering ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Decides to put you away quick,Which would send you straight to LIMB-O, ha ha ha.But just a word in your ear, if you’ve got one.Mind you DO take this in the right spirit,And keep a civil tongue in your head about Me.Because if you DON’T,I’ve got plenty of other stuff up My sleeve,Such as Leukemia and polio,(Which incidentally your welcome to any time,Whatever spirit you take this in.)I’ve given you one love-pat, right?You don’t want another.So watch it, Jack.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Take Sim City, Send it to the Carribean, You got Tropico 4.For those who haven't played any type of Sim City:Tropico puts you in power of a Third World Country. You are tasked to make it into something noticable wether that'd be a tourist trap, industrial/resource export powerhouse, or a self sufficient (I can't spell) nation. You will have to worry about rebel uprisings, foriegn relations that could end in war, natural disasters, factions such as Captialists, Communists, etc etc, and Islands Conditions overall.I love it. I can't be like the rest of people who compare it to 3 and 5 cause this is my first Tropico. From what I read Tropico 3 is almost the same, but I am super excited about this game and will never regret getting it.

content:
Posted: March 26
												On the very first mission, if you fully populate the island, the path-finding algorithm for each citizen breaks, and you get to watch an epic marathon of 5,000 people walking in a 20-mile circle.This is the first mission.  If the game breaks when you fully colonize the map, then why make maps that big, or why let development happen on that long of a cycle?Tried the second mission.  Same exact problem occurs.  There are allegedly 18-more missions.  Do NONE of these work???Kalypso admits this fault, and they put together a rather shabby hack to fix it, http://forum.kalypsomedia.com/showthread.php?tid=12080 (I hope you have 20+ years coding like I do).  Long-story short, Kalypso's hack is basically saying, "This game is not repairable."What happened while I was waiting for Kalypso to fix this?  They release ANOTHER TROPICO GAME!!!  (which also has the same exact blundersome flaws)Scam, stay away.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												I previously wrote a positive review for this game. Even though I deleted it, all the things I said in it are still valid - Tropico is fun, laid back and quite deep. However, I can't give a positive review to a game with this much DLC. Especially when you consider what some of the DLC is (for example, a cement factory DLC because the base game is poorly designed and builders don't construct things fast enough). Players should pay for a game once and then own the full game, not pay for it once and then pay ten more times for all the extra content.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												The world is changing and Tropico is moving with the times - geographical powers rise and fall and the world market is dominated by new players with new demands and offers - and you, as El Presidente, face a whole new set of challenges. If you are to triumph over your naysayers you will need to gain as much support from your people as possible. Your decisions will shape the future of your nation, and more importantly, the size of your off-shore bank account. Tropico 4 expands on the gameplay of the previous game with new political additions ∼ including more superpowers to negotiate with, along with the ability to elect ministers into power to help get your more controversial policies passed. But remember to keep your friends close and your enemies closer as everyone has an agenda! Your political mettle will be thoroughly tested, as new natural disasters will have the populace clamoring for you and your cabinet to help them recover from some of the worst Mother Nature can dish out. Tropico 4 also brings a new level of social interaction with the addition of Facebook and Twitter integration. Post comments on Twitter direct from the game and have updates go out when you complete missions or unlock new achievements. You can even take screenshots of your burgeoning island and post your dream creation on your Tropico 4 Facebook page and compare your interactive Dictator Ranking on the online leaderboards.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												I like the music, it compliments the somewhat subtle homoerotic undertones. The smooth and calming music flows forward without any cuts to hint that the transition between spanking and homoeroticism is almost fluid and could carry over to a possible opening up between these two characters later one, despite the obvious straight mentality that the "the thief" and "the punisher/executioner" have.What do the characters symbolize? The Thief could very symbolize childhood innocence towards himself and his inner sexuality. His act of stealing money by pretending to be some one that he is not is actually a very deep symbolic description of those who have to hide themselves and their sexuality from the world, the actual act of stealing is his repressed side coming out in a violent and destructive manner, hurting others and society similar to how Foucault believes happens in the modern world (by calling his friend and bragging about it is his silent cry for help, similar as to how a man in depression will lash out, hoping that someone will save him, also ironically drawing distance from himself and others).Now this is where the clip take a broad statement that I am having trouble figuring out. The punisher/executioner could very well be either a strong representation of society's view on sexuality or a representative figure of either sexual liberation or an actual shadow/other of the beneficial side of his sexuality, trying to show that his discovery of his sexuality would actually bring him happiness and not pain.If we look at The Executioner aspect (the aspect that the man with the belt is a symbol of society) than we can see a great disgust with modern society's treatment of sexuality. The man, upon learning of The Thief's stealing caused by his repression, chooses to punishes The Thief instead of treating or caring for him for his "criminal reportable" offense. He toys with The Thief before he tells him of his punishment, similar as to how a man can be arrested and be kept detained before he goes to court. Meanwhile the clip points out an even more disgusting feature of The Executioner aspect: the entire time, he is shirtless.What does this mean? The director points out that for The Thief's crimes, society itself is also guilty. Not only does The Executioner shirtlessness points out that in modern society that condemns sexuality, we also promote it blatantly in advertisements, porn, and almost every aspect of our lives, causing confusion and angst in today's youth. We can even go as far as saying that what the director means is that every person in society is in some sense not always in the social conformity, and that people will always have some sexual aspect of themselves that is not socially acceptable (as The Thief's nature points out, by trying to fit into a standard people will inevitable cause pain in both themselves and those around them).Since as I mention the act of spanking is in itself a homoerotic action, than we can know that the symbolism here is that even the act of punishing someone for their sexuality brings up a somewhat devastating sexual act on the social norm--even in punishment we see traces of sexuality, which the social norm would say shouldn't be there. Here, the director makes a great humanistic expression that we can never fully repress our sexual nature, and that society should cast away its judgements and punishments about sexuality. Instead, embracing it in order to bring happiness and a more progressive society.But if we look at The Punisher aspect (where the man with the belt is a sexual liberator), we see something entirely different. Upon hearing The Thief's bragging, he recognizes the repressed cry for help, and choose to punish The Thief to bring liberation. By bending The Thief over and committing the homoerotic act of whipping punishment, he shows through the hidden sexual nature of The Thief. Subconsciously, he presents an act that is subtly sexual in nature, and what will surprise The Thief is that he enjoys it. He would, metaphorically speaking, find out that what he thought would bring him pain instead brings him pleasure.Inevitable he would recognize the act as sexual and will compare the punishment experience with every aspect of his sexuality, gradually loosing himself up to the idea that sexuality would, instead of pain, bring happiness to him. He will in the end change his position that his sexuality will bring harm to himself to the (true) idea that it will bring only happiness to him.Something to note is that in both cases of The Punisher/Executioner aspects is that The Man With The Belt calls his mother, who he first brings with a peaceful idea of sexual punishment but instead she suggests the more violent whipping. Anyone with a brain can figure out that this is a subversion of the Oedipus Complex, The Electra Complex. Where, the father figure being the Man With The Belt, and the mother being the mother. Here, the Mother is a figure with whom is associated with violence, and The Father being the one who the son commits the sexual act with. But since the spanking is the Mothers idea and yet the Father carries it out, what we have here is a subversion of the subversion: The Father and The Mother who are both separate, are also the same person. Since The Thief's sexuality is muddled, both his father and mother have become one person in his mind, both of them he wants to murder, and both of them he wants to have sex with.Ultimately, since the subversion happens on more toward The Electra Complex instead of the Oedipus Complex, I would have to say that it is possible that the two men may perhaps have their sexuality leaning more on the Homosexual aspects than any straight aspects. Which is shocking, the director is implying that these by the books, straight as can be white dudes may be homosexuals! Of course I may be reaching, but what audacity would it take for a director to show two perfect straight men by our social standards, and then spit on the face of our preconceptions by showing they may actually be homosexuals! Again, I of course could be misreading and misinterpreting, since the blatant nature of their straightness is so almost painfully obvious, but as far as we know, they do show signs of homosexuality, but if they truly commit to that nature would require the viewing of the whole movie, or more intelligent film scholars in future generations.I hope that today's and tomorrows generations can all see this clip and be reinvigorated by it. The director's call for sexual liberation is so heartbreakingly honest that it almost brings tears to my eyes. Perhaps one day we can stand by the light of our sexually invigorated sun, be bathed in its light, and take in this clips message as one of the most important statements that was ever made in our time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												I'm new to the Tropico series but have played other real-time simulation games like SimCity and Caesar (the latter of which appears to be the closest parallel to Tropico in my gaming experience).  I'm now eight boards into the campaign and have figured some things out.  As other reviewers have pointed out, the game is very difficult to lose, but it can be challenging for a new player to determine why their city isn't growing as fast as they'd hope or why certain problems persist (certain buildings constantly lack for workers, etc.).  The truth is that despite the slapstick banana-republic-tinpot-autocrat gloss of the game, this is actually a surprisingly deep simulation, and the game will throw a lot of information at you that is easy to lose sight of but important to keep track of.  Build-and-forget does not work.  Even the soil quality or climate of parts of the island can change, meaning that a zone that was ideal for farming a particular crop at the start of the game may not stay that way.The most frustrating thing about the game is traffic management.  Most specifically, your tinpot dictator and his (or her) crack team of mad scientists and engineers might be able to build a nuclear program or an airport, but are congenitally incapable of building a four-lane road.  (One wonders how the planes land if Tropico's scientific community is so deep in its principled opposition to wide stretches of asphalt or concrete.)  There are also occasional graphical glitches and stability issues, but nothing too frequent or catastrophic on my 2008-vintage PC.A solid title and worth the price, especially on a Steam sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Plays a lot like it's previous title, Tropico 3 and other City Sim games like Sim City 2k. However, I do like the ability of being able to choose which super-power you choose to side or not side with, being the US or the USSR. Additionally, the different backgrounds that you can choose in the game reflect which factions of your inhabitants will like you more or less. Being placed by the CIA, means that you start with greater affection with the US and being a Green Thumb background means that the environmentalist faction will be more likely to vote for you and not rebel against you... I have not gotten to the point where my army could not fight back against the Rebels, so I don't know what exactly happens when they overthrow your government... I assume you choose from the following: death, or exile....And not that a majority of people notice, but the Cubano Jazz inspired soundtrack is just simply refreshing to find in a modern game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												So at first I was a bit skeptical about this game. I loved the setting of the game, the sarcasm and humor of the characters, and the beautufl graphics, but I was not sure I would actually enjoy the gameplay very much. I was worried that it would either feel too sandboxy, with no goals, nothing to strive for except building your island, or that it would be not sandboxy enough, more like a narrative than a city builder game. It turns out, it struck a beautiful balance between the two. There are goals, quests, and tasks to complete, but you can do them any way you choose, or choose to completely ignore them if you prefer. I have never felt lost while playing the game, but have rarely felt restricted, or like the game was forcing me down a path I didn't want. This is an extremely difficult balancing point to achieve, but this game absolutely nailed it.Highly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2012
												An interesting mix of a building sim and diplomatic strategy game.  The campaigns are fairly straight-forward in that, in order, to complete them you really just need to fulfill the main quests.  Each campaign has a unique island (20 total) with a different element to make it interesting.  For example, one level you are caught in the middle of the Cold War with the US and USSR ready to bomb one another at a moments notice.  You have to keep the DEFCON level up otherwise the world will explode.  In another level, you might have a resource rich island where exports of raw goods will make you rich and in another you might have a resource-lacking island where industry and imports or tourism are your only way of making money. The game contains lots of humorous content including a frequent radio show (some jokes repeat after some time) and really funny voice acting with some inching-on-racism stereotypes.I picked this up for $8 and I've gotten more than my money's worth without any DLCs.  I highly recommend this game as a respite from the frustrating multi-player games out there.4/5 Stars

												Tropico is a good change if most of your library is explosions and death. You build your city, you can answer the needs of factions to have them like you or not. content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Brings an economic side to all those strategy games, although it does have combat. Overall it is a good game. Unlike other economic strategy games which are broad ("Build a Farm" - what sort of farm? Pig farm? Cow Farm? Ladybug farm?) it is much like stronghold, in the way that it is more specific for each category (E.G you can choose a weapon factory, furniture etc.) although that does come at a cost (just like in stronghold) as it limits the amount of categories there are. However this does not impact on the game. Suggestions? The AI is extremely easy, and you can almost never loose an election. Buy this when on sale. Plenty of fun.

												Tropico is a city builder with an actual game behind it. You design everything from the roads to where individual buildings are placed, and fund it by creating a strong economy.
